Vaginervose: Having the nerves, or veins, placed in apparent disorder.
Vaudois: An inhabitant, or the inhabitants, of the Swiss canton of Vaud.
Veratrum: A genus of coarse liliaceous herbs having very poisonous qualities.
Vendible: Something to be sold, or offered for sale.
Verbena: A genus of herbaceous plants of which several species are extensively cultivated for the great beauty of their flowers; vervain.
Vernier: A short scale made to slide along the divisions of a graduated instrument, as the limb of a sextant, or the scale of a barometer, for indicating parts of divisions. It is so graduated that a certain convenient number of its divisions are just equal to a certain number, either one less or one more, of the divisions of the instrument, so that parts of a division are determined by observing what line on the vernier coincides with a line on the instrument.
Vestibular: Of or pertaining to a vestibule; like a vestibule.
Vagueness: The quality or state of being vague.
Volley: To be thrown out, or discharged, at once; to be discharged in a volley, or as if in a volley; to make a volley or volleys.
Vasodentine: A modified form of dentine, which is permeated by blood capillaries; vascular dentine.
Voltairism: The theories or practice of Voltaire.
Ventose: The sixth month of the calendar adopted by the first French republic. It began February 19, and ended March 20.  See Vendémiaire.
Vasoformative: Concerned in the development and formation of blood vessels and blood corpuscles; as, the vasoformative cells.
Verderer: An officer who has the charge of the king's forest, to preserve the vert and venison, keep the assizes, view, receive, and enroll attachments and presentments of all manner of trespasses.
Volatileness: Quality or state of being volatile; disposition to evaporate; changeableness; fickleness.
Vatican Council: The council held under Pope Pius IX. in Vatican at Rome, in 1870, which promulgated the dogma of papal infallibility.
Version: A change of form, direction, or the like; transformation; conversion; turning.
Vigilance: The quality or state of being vigilant; forbearance of sleep; wakefulness.
Vineal: Of or pertaining to vines; containing vines.
Valsalvian: Of or pertaining to Valsalva, an Italian anatomist of the 17th century.
Vulgarian: A vulgar person; one who has vulgar ideas. Used also adjectively.
Vitamin: any of several organic chemical substances not synthesized by an animal and required in small quantities for normal metabolism, present in and obtained from the natural foods eaten by the animal.  Human vitamins are also produced synthetically, and taken in pure form or in mixtures, as dietary supplements.  Deficiencies of specific vitamins lead to certain specific disorders, such as scurvy, caused by an insufficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
Vitreous: Consisting of, or resembling, glass; glassy; as, vitreous rocks.
Visual: Of or pertaining to sight; used in sight; serving as the instrument of seeing; as, the visual nerve.
Vizier: A councilor of state; a high executive officer in Turkey and other Oriental countries.
Venditate: To cry up. as if for sale; to blazon.
Vestry: A room appendant to a church, in which sacerdotal vestments and sacred utensils are sometimes kept, and where meetings for worship or parish business are held; a sacristy; -- formerly called revestiary.
Vial: To put in a vial or vials.
Vitrics: The art or study of the manufacture and decoration of glassware.
Votaress: A woman who is a votary.
Voltage: Electric potential or potential difference, expressed in volts.
Verge: To border upon; to tend; to incline; to come near; to approach.
Voiceless: Having no voice, utterance, or vote; silent; mute; dumb.
Vidual: Of or pertaining to the state of a widow; widowed.
Vesicle: A bladderlike vessel; a membranous cavity; a cyst; a cell.
Virulence: The quality or state of being virulent or venomous; poisonousness; malignancy.
Ventriculite: Any one of numerous species of siliceous fossil sponges belonging to Ventriculites and allied genera, characteristic of the Cretaceous period.
vividity: The quality or state of being vivid; vividness.
Vesselful: As much as a vessel will hold; enough to fill a vessel.
Vernicose: Having a brilliantly polished surface, as some leaves.
Vegetarian: Of or pertaining to vegetarianism; as, a vegetarian diet.
Veiny: Full of veins; veinous; veined; as, veiny marble.
V: V, the twenty-second letter of the English alphabet, is a vocal consonant. V and U are only varieties of the same character, U being the cursive form, while V is better adapted for engraving, as in stone. The two letters were formerly used indiscriminately, and till a comparatively recent date words containing them were often classed together in dictionaries and other books of reference (see U). The letter V is from the Latin alphabet, where it was used both as a consonant (about like English w) and as a vowel. The Latin derives it from a form (V) of the Greek vowel Υ (see Y), this Greek letter being either from the same Semitic letter as the digamma F (see F), or else added by the Greeks to the alphabet which they took from the Semitic. Etymologically v is most nearly related to u, w, f, b, p; as in vine, wine; avoirdupois, habit, have; safe, save; trover, troubadour, trope. See U, F, etc.
Volcanic: Of or pertaining to a volcano or volcanoes; as, volcanic heat.
Vibratility: The quality or state of being vibratile; disposition to vibration or oscillation.
Vespertiliones: A tribe of bats including the common insectivorous bats of America and Europe, belonging to Vespertilio and allied genera.  They lack a nose membrane.
Vacuometer: An instrument for the comparison of barometers.
Venturine: Gold powder for covering varnished surfaces.
Viceroyalty: The dignity, office, or jurisdiction of a viceroy.
Virtual: Having the power of acting or of invisible efficacy without the agency of the material or sensible part; potential; energizing.
Viduage: The state of widows or of widowhood; also, widows, collectively.
Visional: Of or pertaining to a vision.
Venerable: Capable of being venerated; worthy of veneration or reverence; deserving of honor and respect; -- generally implying an advanced age; as, a venerable magistrate; a venerable parent.
Ventouse: To cup; to use a cupping glass.
Vaccine: The virus of vaccinia used in vaccination.
Vertically: In a vertical manner, position, or direction; perpendicularly; as, to look down vertically; to raise a thing vertically.
Virginal: To play with the fingers, as if on a virginal; to tap or pat.
Verdoy: Charged with leaves, fruits, flowers, etc.; -- said of a border.
Vizier-azem: A grand vizier.  See under Vizier.
Vibrissa: One of the specialized or tactile hairs which grow about the nostrils, or on other parts of the face, in many animals, as the so-called whiskers of the cat, and the hairs of the nostrils of man.
Varify: To make different; to vary; to variegate.
Vigesimation: The act of putting to death every twentieth man.
Vulpes: A genus of Carnivora including the foxes.
Vagrancy: The quality or state of being a vagrant; a wandering without a settled home; an unsettled condition; vagabondism.
Verbose: Abounding in words; using or containing more words than are necessary; tedious by a multiplicity of words; prolix; wordy; as, a verbose speaker; a verbose argument.
Vergeboard: The ornament of woodwork upon the gable of a house, used extensively in the 15th century. It was generally suspended from the edge of the projecting roof (see Verge, n., 4), and in a position parallel to the gable wall. Called also bargeboard.
Variometer: An instrument for comparing magnetic forces, esp. in the earth's magnetic field.
Vocality: The quality or state of being vocal; utterableness; resonance; as, the vocality of the letters.
Verbality: The quality or state of being verbal; mere words; bare literal expression.
Vitro-di-trina: A kind of Venetian glass or glassware in which white threads are embedded in transparent glass with a lacelike or netlike effect.
Vanglo: Benne (Sesamum orientale); also, its seeds; -- so called in the West Indies.
Viable: Capable of living; born alive and with such form and development of organs as to be capable of living; -- said of a newborn, or a prematurely born, infant.
Viticulose: Having long and slender trailing stems.
Vomiting: The spasmodic ejection of matter from the stomach through the mouth.
Vesiculate: To form vesicles in, as lava.
Vickers-Maxim gun: One of a system of ordnance, including machine, quick-fire, coast, and field guns, of all calibers, manufactured by the combined firms of Vickers' Sons of Sheffield and Maxim of Birmingham and elsewhere, England.
Veery: An American thrush (Turdus fuscescens) common in the Northern United States and Canada. It is light tawny brown above. The breast is pale buff, thickly spotted with brown. Called also Wilson's thrush.
Volva: A saclike envelope of certain fungi, which bursts open as the plant develops.
Vetiver: An East Indian grass (Andropogon muricatus); also, its fragrant roots which are much used for making mats and screens.  Also called kuskus, and khuskhus.
Valvula: A little valve or fold; a valvelet; a valvule.
Verificative: Serving to verify; verifying; authenticating; confirming.
Vocule: A short or weak utterance; a faint or feeble sound, as that heard on separating the lips in pronouncing p or b.
Vafrous: Crafty; cunning; sly; as, vafrous tricks.
Vigonia: Of or pertaining to the vicuña; characterizing the vicuña; -- said of the wool of that animal, used in felting hats, and for other purposes.
Vodka: A Russian drink distilled from rye.
Victress: A woman who wins a victory; a female victor.
Vitta: One of the oil tubes in the fruit of umbelliferous plants.
Venery: The art, act, or practice of hunting; the sports of the chase.
Verity: The quality or state of being true, or real; consonance of a statement, proposition, or other thing, with fact; truth; reality.
Vasculose: One of the substances of which vegetable tissue is composed, differing from cellulose in respect to its solubility in certain media.
Venge: To avenge; to punish; to revenge.
Verdurous: Covered with verdure; clothed with the fresh green of vegetation; verdured; verdant; as, verdurous pastures.
Valued: Highly regarded; esteemed; prized; as, a valued contributor; a valued friend.
Vortex fringe: The region immediately surrounding a disk moving flatwise through air; -- so called because the air has a cyclic motion as in vortex ring.
videotape: a video recording made on magnetic tape.
Vice-regal: Of or pertaining to a viceroy or viceroyalty.
Vaginula: A little sheath, as that about the base of the pedicel of most mosses.
Vaccary: A cow house, dairy house, or cow pasture.
Voortreker: One who treks before or first; a pioneer.
Vaishnava: A worshiper of the god Vishnu in any of his incarnations.
Vulnerary: Useful in healing wounds; adapted to the cure of external injuries; as, vulnerary plants or potions.
Voluta: Any one of numerous species of large, handsome marine gastropods belonging to Voluta and allied genera.
Vanfoss: A ditch on the outside of the counterscarp, usually full of water.
Vitelligenous: Producing yolk, or vitelline substance; -- applied to certain cells (also called nutritive, or yolk, cells) formed in the ovaries of many insects, and supposed to supply nutriment to the developing ova.
Vatful: As much as a vat will hold; enough to fill a vat.
Vested school: In Ireland, a national school which has been built by the aid of grants from the board of Commissioners of National Education and is secured for educational purposes by leases to the commissioners themselves, or to the commissioners and the trustees.
Via: By the way of; as, to send a letter via Queenstown to London.
Vegeto-animal: Partaking of the nature both of vegetable and animal matter; -- a term sometimes applied to vegetable albumen and gluten, from their resemblance to similar animal products.
Vavasory: The quality or tenure of the fee held by a vavasor; also, the lands held by a vavasor.
Veneficial: Acting by poison; used in poisoning or in sorcery.
Vie: A contest for superiority; competition; rivalry; strife; also, a challenge; a wager.
Visitor: One who visits; one who comes or goes to see another, as in civility or friendship.
Vine: Any woody climbing plant which bears grapes.
Vastness: The quality or state of being vast.
Veranda: An open, roofed gallery or portico, adjoining a dwelling house, forming an out-of-door sitting room.  See Loggia.
Voluted: Having a volute, or spiral scroll.
Vulcanizer: One who, or that which, vulcanizes; esp., an apparatus for vulcanizing caoutchouc.
Vivency: Manner of supporting or continuing life or vegetation.
Vibration: The act of vibrating, or the state of being vibrated, or in vibratory motion; quick motion to and fro; oscillation, as of a pendulum or musical string.
Vortex ring: A ring-shaped mass of moving fluid which, by virtue of its motion of rotation around an axis disposed in circular form, attains a more or less distinct separation from the surrounding medium and has many of the properties of a solid.
Vickers gun: One of a system of guns manufactured by the firm of Vickers' Sons, at Sheffield, Eng. now included in Vickers-Maxim guns.
Vanadic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, vanadium; containing vanadium; specifically, designating those compounds in which vanadium has a relatively higher valence as contrasted with the vanadous compounds; as, vanadic oxide.
Veneering: The act or art of one who veneers.
Vindication: The act of vindicating, or the state of being vindicated; defense; justification against denial or censure; as, the vindication of opinions; his vindication is complete.
Visible speech: A system of characters invented by Prof. Alexander Melville Bell to represent all sounds that may be uttered by the speech organs, and intended to be suggestive of the position of the organs of speech in uttering them.
Vermuth: A liqueur made of white wine, absinthe, and various aromatic drugs, used to excite the appetite.
Vanadium: A rare element of the nitrogen-phosphorus group, found combined, in vanadates, in certain minerals, and reduced as an infusible, grayish-white metallic powder. It is intermediate between the metals and the non-metals, having both basic and acid properties. Symbol V (or Vd, rarely). Atomic weight 50.94 (C12=12.000).
Verbosity: The quality or state of being verbose; the use of more words than are necessary; prolixity; wordiness; verbiage.
Verticillaster: A whorl of flowers apparently of one cluster, but composed of two opposite axillary cymes, as in mint.  See Illust. of Whorl.
Vintaging: The act of gathering the vintage, or crop of grapes.
Vanillic: Pertaining to, or derived from, vanilla or vanillin; resembling vanillin; specifically, designating an alcohol and an acid respectively, vanillin being the intermediate aldehyde.
Vanillin: A white crystalline aldehyde having a burning taste and characteristic odor of vanilla. It is extracted from vanilla pods, and is also obtained by the decomposition of coniferin, and by the oxidation of eugenol.
Vitalist: A believer in the theory of vitalism; -- opposed to physicist.
Vitalism: The doctrine that all the functions of a living organism are due to an unknown vital principle distinct from all chemical and physical forces.
Volumetric: Of or pertaining to the measurement of volume.
Vertebrata: One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom, comprising all animals that have a backbone composed of bony or cartilaginous vertebræ, together with Amphioxus in which the backbone is represented by a simple undivided notochord. The Vertebrata always have a dorsal, or neural, cavity above the notochord or backbone, and a ventral, or visceral, cavity below it. The subdivisions or classes of Vertebrata are Mammalia, Aves, Reptilia, Amphibia, Pisces, Marsipobranchia, and Leptocardia.
Villous: Abounding in, or covered with, fine hairs, or a woolly substance; shaggy with soft hairs; nappy.
Vertebrate: Having a backbone, or vertebral column, containing the spinal marrow, as man, quadrupeds, birds, amphibia, and fishes.
Vampire: A blood-sucking ghost; a soul of a dead person superstitiously believed to come from the grave and wander about by night sucking the blood of persons asleep, thus causing their death.  This superstition was once prevalent in parts of Eastern Europe, and was especially current in Hungary about the year 1730.  The vampire was often said to have the ability to transform itself into the form of a bat, as presented in the novel depicting the legend of Dracula published by Bram Stoker in 1897, which has inspired several movies.
Vermiculated: Made or marked with irregular wavy lines or impressions; vermiculate.
Vitalization: The act or process of vitalizing, or infusing the vital principle.
Vesication: The process of vesicating, or of raising blisters.
Variableness: The quality or state of being variable; variability.
Visayan: A member of the most numerous of the native races of the Philippines, occupying the Visayan Islands and the northern coast Mindanao; also, their language. The Visayans possessed a native culture and alphabet.
Vicarial: Of or pertaining to a vicar; as, vicarial tithes.
Vacillancy: The quality or state of being vacillant, or wavering.
Vanguard: The troops who march in front of an army; the advance guard; the van.
Vexation: The act of vexing, or the state of being vexed; agitation; disquiet; trouble; irritation.
Vision: To see in a vision; to dream.
Viscountcy: The dignity or jurisdiction of a viscount.
Vell: To cut the turf from, as for burning.
Vegetability: The quality or state of being vegetable.
Voiced: Furnished with a voice; expressed by the voice.
Vespertilio: A genus of bats including some of the common small insectivorous species of North America and Europe.
Ventilate: To open and expose to the free passage of air; to supply with fresh air, and remove impure air from; to air; as, to ventilate a room; to ventilate a cellar; to ventilate a mine.
Valylene: A volatile liquid hydrocarbon, C5H6, related to ethylene and acetylene, but possessing the property of unsaturation in the third degree.  It is the only known member of a distinct series of compounds.  It has a garlic odor.
Voluptuous: Full of delight or pleasure, especially that of the senses; ministering to sensuous or sensual gratification; exciting sensual desires; luxurious; sensual.
Virtueless: Destitute of virtue; without efficacy or operating qualities; powerless.
Veiled: Covered by, or as by, a veil; hidden.
Valkyrian: Of or pertaining to the Valkyries; hence, relating to battle.
Vulcanize: To change the properties of, as caoutchouc, or India rubber, by the process of vulcanization.
Vindemial: Of or pertaining to a vintage, or grape harvest.
Vicu\u00f1a: A South American mammal (Auchenia vicunna) native of the elevated plains of the Andes, allied to the llama but smaller. It has a thick coat of very fine reddish brown wool, and long, pendent white hair on the breast and belly. It is hunted for its wool and flesh.
Verrugas: An endemic disease occurring in the Andes in Peru, characterized by warty tumors which ulcerate and bleed. It is probably due to a special bacillus, and is often fatal.
Villenous: Of or pertaining to a villein.
Vedanta: A system of philosophy among the Hindus, founded on scattered texts of the Vedas, and thence termed the “Anta,” or end or substance.
Venturous: Daring; bold; hardy; fearless; venturesome; adventurous; as, a venturous soldier.
Vasum: A genus including several species of large marine gastropods having massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on the columella.
Volitive: Of or pertaining to the will; originating in the will; having the power to will.
Vanjas: The Australian pied crow shrike (Strepera graculina). It is glossy bluish black, with the under tail coverts and the tips and bases of the tail feathers white.
Vindicatory: Tending or serving to vindicate or justify; justificatory; vindicative.
Vortex line: A line, within a rotating fluid, whose tangent at every point is the instantaneous axis of rotation as that point of the fluid.
Vibrator: One that vibrates, or causes vibration or oscillation of any kind;
Vehiculate: To convey by means of a vehicle; to ride in a vehicle.
Volcanize: To subject to, or cause to undergo, volcanic heat, and to be affected by its action.
Vulturine: Of or pertaining to a vulture; resembling a vulture in qualities or looks; as, the vulturine sea eagle (Gypohierax Angolensis); vulturine rapacity.
Valerone: A ketone of valeric acid obtained as an oily liquid.
Vinification: The conversion of a fruit juice or other saccharine solution into alcohol by fermentation.
Vinometer: An instrument for determining the strength or purity of wine by measuring its density.
Veronica: A portrait or representation of the face of our Savior on the alleged handkerchief of Saint Veronica, preserved at Rome; hence, a representation of this portrait, or any similar representation of the face of the Savior.  Formerly called also Vernacle, and Vernicle.
Vinegarroon: A whip scorpion, esp. a large Mexican species (Thelyphonus giganteus) popularly supposed to be very venomous; -- from the odor that it emits when alarmed.
Vomition: The act or power of vomiting.
Vascularization: The process of becoming vascular, or the condition of being vascular; as, the vascularization of cartilege.
Vibrio: A genus of motile bacteria characterized by short, slightly sinuous filaments and an undulatory motion; also, an individual of this genus.
Verst: A Russian measure of length containing 3,500 English feet.
Voracity: The quality of being voracious; voraciousness.
Vanadite: A salt of vanadious acid, analogous to a nitrite or a phosphite.
Verso: The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet of paper; -- opposed to recto.
Vocabulary: A list or collection of words arranged in alphabetical order and explained; a dictionary or lexicon, either of a whole language, a single work or author, a branch of science, or the like; a word-book.
Vortex tube: An imaginary tube within a rotating fluid, formed by drawing the vortex lines through all points of a closed curve.
Vesiculation: The state of containing vesicles, or the process by which vesicles are formed.
Viperine: Of or pertaining to a viper or vipers; resembling a viper.
Vice: Denoting one who in certain cases may assume the office or duties of a superior; designating an officer or an office that is second in rank or authority; as, vice president; vice agent; vice consul, etc.
Vibrant: Vibrating; tremulous; resonant; as, vibrant drums.
Velarium: The marginal membrane of certain medusæ belonging to the Discophora.
Verdict: The answer of a jury given to the court concerning any matter of fact in any cause, civil or criminal, committed to their examination and determination; the finding or decision of a jury on the matter legally submitted to them in the course of the trial of a cause.
Vide: imperative sing. of L. videre, to see; -- used to direct attention to something; as, vide supra, see above.
Vanadious: Pertaining to, or containing, vanadium; specifically, designating those compounds in which vanadium has a lower valence as contrasted with the vanadic compounds; as, vanadious acid.  Usually written vanadous.
Viscidity: The quality or state of being viscid; also, that which is viscid; glutinous concretion; stickiness.
vernal: Of or pertaining to the spring; appearing in the spring; as, vernal bloom.
Vomica: An abscess cavity in the lungs.
Vandalism: The spirit or conduct of the Vandals; ferocious cruelty; hostility to the arts and literature, or willful destruction or defacement of any object of beauty or value.
Vermeology: A discourse or treatise on worms; that part of zoölogy which treats of worms; helminthology.
Volubility: The quality or state of being voluble (in any of the senses of the adjective).
Vadantes: An extensive artificial group of birds including the wading, swimming, and cursorial birds.
Virtually: In a virtual manner; in efficacy or effect only, and not actually; to all intents and purposes; practically.
videocasette recorder: an electronic device which can record electronic signals, as from a television program, on magnetic tape contained in a videocassette, and can also play back the recording.  It is used, for example, to record television programs broadcast at some particular time, which can then be viewed at any subsequent time by attaching the videocasette recorder to a television receiver and playing the signals throught the television receiver.  Also called VCR.
Visigoth: One of the West Goths.  See the Note under Goth.
Variation: The act of varying; a partial change in the form, position, state, or qualities of a thing; modification; alteration; mutation; diversity; deviation; as, a variation of color in different lights; a variation in size; variation of language.
Villanize: To make vile; to debase; to degrade; to revile.
Verein: A union, association, or society; -- used in names of German organizations.
Versant: The slope of a side of a mountain chain; hence, the general slope of a country; aspect.
Veldt: A region or tract of land; esp., the open field, thinly forested or with bushes and shrubs; grass country.
Valero-: A combining form (also used adjectively) indicating derivation from, or relation to, valerian or some of its products, as valeric acid; as in valerolactone, a colorless oily liquid produced as the anhydride of an hydroxy valeric acid.
Voltmeter: An instrument for measuring in volts the differences of potential between different points of an electrical circuit.
Vitiligo: A rare skin disease consisting in the development of smooth, milk-white spots upon various parts of the body.
Variety show: A stage entertainment, live or televised, of successive separate performances, usually songs, dances, acrobatic feats, dramatic sketches, exhibitions of trained animals, or any specialties. When performed live in a theater, it was often called a vaudeville show, but when television became a dominant form of entertainment live vaudeville performances almost completely ceased.
Volatilize: To render volatile; to cause to exhale or evaporate; to cause to pass off in vapor.
Vitalistic: Pertaining to, or involving, vitalism, or the theory of a special vital principle.
Violet-ear: Any tropical humming bird of the genus Petasophora, having violet or purplish ear tufts.
Viroled: Furnished with a virole or viroles; -- said of a horn or a bugle when the rings are of different tincture from the rest of the horn.
Vulvovaginal: Pertaining both to the vulva and the vagina.
Virile: Having the nature, properties, or qualities, of an adult man; characteristic of developed manhood; hence, masterful; forceful; specifically, capable of begetting; -- opposed to womanly, feminine, and puerile; as, virile age, virile power, virile organs.
Voodoo: Of or pertaining to voodooism, or a voodoo; as, voodoo incantations.
Voussoir: One of the wedgelike stones of which an arch is composed.
Voter: One who votes; one who has a legal right to vote, or give his suffrage; an elector; a suffragist; as, an independent voter.
Vespertine: Of or pertaining to the evening; happening or being in the evening.
Venesection: The act or operation of opening a vein for letting blood; bloodletting; phlebotomy.
Vesting: Cloth for vests; a vest pattern.
Viviparous: Producing young in a living state, as most mammals, or as those plants the offspring of which are produced alive, either by bulbs instead of seeds, or by the seeds themselves germinating on the plant, instead of falling, as they usually do; -- opposed to oviparous.
Vauntful: Given to vaunting or boasting; vainly ostentatious; boastful; vainglorious.
Violaceous: Resembling violets in color; bluish purple.
Virole: A ring surrounding a bugle or hunting horn.
Valedictorian: One who pronounces a valedictory address; especially, in American colleges, the student who pronounces the valedictory of the graduating class at the annual commencement, usually the student who ranks first in scholarship.
Virescent: Beginning to be green; slightly green; greenish.
Ventricular: Of or pertaining to a ventricle; bellied.
Vegetality: The quality or state of being vegetal, or vegetable.
Vapulation: The act of beating or whipping.
Viaduct: A structure of considerable magnitude, usually with arches or supported on trestles, for carrying a road, as a railroad, high above the ground or water; a bridge; especially, one for crossing a valley or a gorge.  Cf. Trestlework.
Volge: The common sort of people; the crowd; the mob.
Valentine: A sweetheart chosen on St. Valentine's Day.
Vidame: One of a class of temporal officers who originally represented the bishops, but later erected their offices into fiefs, and became feudal nobles.
Vienna paste: A caustic application made up of equal parts of caustic potash and quicklime; -- called also Vienna caustic.
Valued-policy law: A law requiring insurance companies to pay to the insured, in case of total loss, the full amount of the insurance, regardless of the actual value of the property at the time of the loss.
Venin: A toxic substance contained in the venom of poisonous snakes; also, a (supposedly identical) toxic substance obtained by the cleavage of an albumose.
Vaccinator: One who, or that which, vaccinates.
Vervet: A South African monkey (Cercopithecus pygerythrus syn. Cercopithecus Lelandii).  The upper parts are grayish green, finely specked with black.  The cheeks and belly are reddish white.
Vanadyl: The hypothetical radical VO, regarded as a characteristic residue of certain vanadium compounds.
Vavasor: The vassal or tenant of a baron; one who held under a baron, and who also had tenants under him; one in dignity next to a baron; a title of dignity next to a baron.
Verisimilitude: The quality or state of being verisimilar; the appearance of truth; probability; likelihood.
Vespa: A genus of Hymenoptera including the common wasps and hornets.
Vessicnon: A soft swelling on a horse's leg; a windgall.
Ventilation: The act of ventilating, or the state of being ventilated; the art or process of replacing foul air by that which is pure, in any inclosed place, as a house, a church, a mine, etc.; free exposure to air.
Vanillyl: The hypothetical radical characteristic of vanillic alcohol.
Virginity: The quality or state of being a virgin; undefiled purity or chastity; maidenhood.
Voe: An inlet, bay, or creek; -- so called in the Orkney and Shetland Islands.
Vouchee: The person who is vouched, or called into court to support or make good his warranty of title in the process of common recovery.
Vermilinguia: A tribe of edentates comprising the South American ant-eaters. The tongue is long, slender, exsertile, and very flexible, whence the name.
Viscerate: To deprive of the viscera, or entrails; to eviscerate; to disembowel.
Volt: The unit of electro-motive force; -- defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893 and by United States Statute as, that electro-motive force which steadily applied to a conductor whose resistance is one ohm will produce a current of one ampère. It is practically equivalent to 1000/1434 the electro-motive force of a standard Clark's cell at a temperature of 15° C.
Vow: To make a vow, or solemn promise.
veterinarian: One skilled in the treatment of diseases of cattle or domestic animals; a veterinary surgeon.  Often abbreviated to vet.
Voucher: One who vouches, or gives witness or full attestation, to anything.
Visceral: Of, pertaining to, or affecting the viscera; splanchnic.
Vista: A view; especially, a view through or between intervening objects, as trees; a view or prospect through an avenue, or the like; hence, the trees or other objects that form the avenue.
Vargueno: A decorative cabinet, of a form originating in Spain, the body being rectangular and supported on legs or an ornamental framework and the front opening downwards on hinges to serve as a writing desk.
Virgin: To act the virgin; to be or keep chaste; -- followed by it.  See It, 5.
Velutina: Any one of several species of marine gastropods belonging to Velutina and allied genera.
Verdine: A commercial name for a green aniline dye.
Vivificate: To give life to; to animate; to revive; to vivify.
Vegetarianism: The theory or practice of living upon vegetables and fruits.
Veliger: Any larval gastropod or bivalve mollusk in the stage when it is furnished with one or two ciliated membranes for swimming.
Volumescope: An instrument consisting essentially of a glass tube provided with a graduated scale, for exhibiting to the eye the changes of volume of a gas or gaseous mixture resulting from chemical action, etc.
Vellication: The act of twitching, or of causing to twitch.
Virtuosoship: The condition, pursuits, or occupation of a virtuoso.
Vociferate: To utter with a loud voice; to shout out.
Valued policy: A policy in which the value of the goods, property, or interest insured is specified; -- opposed to open policy.
Vitrify: To become glass; to be converted into glass.
Videlicet: To wit; namely; -- often abbreviated to viz.
Velvet: To make like, or cover with, velvet.
Vase clock: A clock whose decorative case has the general form of a vase, esp. one in which there is no ordinary dial, but in which a part of a vase revolves while a single stationary indicator serves as a hand.
Vaticinal: Of or pertaining to prophecy; prophetic.
Voltigeur: A tumbler; a leaper or vaulter.
Ventosity: Quality or state of being ventose; windiness; hence, vainglory; pride.
Vetoist: One who uses, or sustains the use of, the veto.
Ventricose: Swelling out on one side or unequally; bellied; ventricular; as, a ventricose corolla.
Vocalism: The exercise of the vocal organs; vocalization.
Vaporability: The quality or state of being vaporable.
Vigoroso: Vigorous; energetic; with energy; -- a direction to perform a passage with energy and force.
Vesicularia: Any one of numerous species of marine Bryozoa belonging to Vesicularia and allied genera. They have delicate tubular cells attached in clusters to slender flexible stems.
vegan: A vegetarian who does not eat any animal products, not even fish, eggs, or milk.
Veneracea: An extensive tribe of bivalve mollusks of which the genus Venus is the type. The shells are usually oval, or somewhat heartshaped, with a conspicuous lunule.  See Venus.
Ventriculous: Somewhat distended in the middle; ventricular.
Vend: The act of vending or selling; a sale.
Vigilant: Attentive to discover and avoid danger, or to provide for safety; wakeful; watchful; circumspect; wary.
Violuric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitroso derivative of barbituric acid. It is obtained as a white or yellow crystalline substance, and forms characteristic yellow, blue, and violet salts.
Vitellogene: A gland secreting the yolk of the eggs in trematodes, turbellarians, and some other helminths.
Vitascope: A form of machine for exhibiting animated pictures.
Valorous: Possessing or exhibiting valor; brave; courageous; valiant; intrepid.
Verdancy: The quality or state of being verdant.
Vapidity: The quality or state of being vapid; vapidness.
Vortex filament: A vortex tube of infinitesimal cross section.
Votary: One devoted, consecrated, or engaged by a vow or promise; hence, especially, one devoted, given, or addicted, to some particular service, worship, study, or state of life.
Vexingly: In a vexing manner; so as to vex, tease, or irritate.
Vervain: Any plant of the genus Verbena.
Vastation: A laying waste; waste; depopulation; devastation.
Vaginicola: A genus of Infusoria which form minute vaselike or tubular cases in which they dwell.
Vettura: An Italian four-wheeled carriage, esp. one let for hire; a hackney coach.
Ventage: A small hole, as the stop in a flute; a vent.
Verrucose: Covered with wartlike elevations; tuberculate; warty; verrucous; as, a verrucose capsule.
Verbiage: The use of many words without necessity, or with little sense; a superabundance of words; verbosity; wordiness.
Venditation: The act of setting forth ostentatiously; a boastful display.
Verminous: Tending to breed vermin; infested by vermin.
Vermifugal: Tending to prevent, destroy, or expel, worms or vermin; anthelmintic.
Veracity: The quality or state of being veracious; habitual observance of truth; truthfulness; truth; as, a man of veracity.
Volunteer navy: A navy of vessels fitted out and manned by volunteers who sail under the flag of the regular navy and subject to naval discipline. Prussia in 1870, in the Franco-German war, organized such a navy, which was commanded by merchant seamen with temporary commissions, with the claim (in which England acquiesced) that it did not come within the meaning of the term privateer.
Viscosimeter: An instrument for measuring the degree of viscosity of liquids, as solutions of gum.
Visit: The act of visiting, or going to see a person or thing; a brief stay of business, friendship, ceremony, curiosity, or the like, usually longer than a call; as, a visit of civility or respect; a visit to Saratoga; the visit of a physician.
Vituperative: Uttering or writing censure; containing, or characterized by, abuse; scolding; abusive.
Vachette clasp: A piece of strong steel wire with the ends curved and pointed, used on toe or quarter cracks to bind the edges together and prevent motion. It is clasped into two notches, one on each side of the crack, burned into the wall with a cautery iron.
Vanquisher: One who, or that which, vanquishes.
Volost: In the greater part of Russia, a division for local government consisting of a group of mirs, or village communities; a canton.
Variate: To alter; to make different; to vary.
Vacuousness: The quality or state of being vacuous; emptiness; vacuity.
Voidable: Capable of being voided, or evacuated.
Valueless: Being of no value; having no worth.
Vernage: A kind of sweet wine from Italy.
Varicocele: A varicose enlargement of the veins of the spermatic cord; also, a like enlargement of the veins of the scrotum.
Venial: Capable of being forgiven; not heinous; excusable; pardonable; as, a venial fault or transgression.
Visa: To indorse, after examination, with the word visé, as a passport; to visé.
Vise: An instrument consisting of two jaws, closing by a screw, lever, cam, or the like, for holding work, as in filing.
Virgalieu: A valuable kind of pear, of an obovate shape and with melting flesh of delicious flavor; -- more properly called White Doyenné.
Vivacious: Having vigorous powers of life; tenacious of life; long-lived.
Vetturino: One who lets or drives a vettura.
Vanquishment: The act of vanquishing, or the state of being vanquished.
Varus: A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See Talipes.
Validate: To confirm; to render valid; to give legal force to.
Vivant: In mort, bridge, and similar games, the partner of dummy.
Vocabulist: The writer or maker of a vocabulary; a lexicographer.
Voluntary: One who engages in any affair of his own free will; a volunteer.
Veratrine: A poisonous alkaloid obtained from the root of hellebore (Veratrum) and from sabadilla seeds as a white crystalline powder, having an acrid, burning taste.  It is sometimes used externally, as in ointments, in the local treatment of neuralgia and rheumatism.  Called also veratria, and veratrina.
Volcanicity: Quality or state of being volcanic; volcanic power.
Ventriloquous: Of or pertaining to a ventriloquist or ventriloquism.
Vacher: A keeper of stock or cattle; a herdsman.
Volubilate: Turning, or whirling; winding; twining; voluble.
Voiceful: Having a voice or vocal quality; having a loud voice or many voices; vocal; sounding.
Violescent: Tending to a violet color; violascent.
Vizierial: Of, pertaining to, or issued by, a vizier.
Vitality: The quality or state of being vital; the principle of life; vital force; animation; as, the vitality of eggs or vegetable seeds; the vitality of an enterprise.
Vulpinism: The quality of being cunning like the fox; craft; artfulness.
Vitiation: The act of vitiating, or the state of being vitiated; depravation; corruption; invalidation; as, the vitiation of the blood; the vitiation of a contract.
Vis\u00e9: To examine and indorse, as a passport; to visa.
Viscacha: A large burrowing South American rodent (Lagostomus trichodactylus) allied to the chinchillas, but much larger. Its fur is soft and rather long, mottled gray above, white or yellowish white beneath. There is a white band across the muzzle, and a dark band on each cheek. It inhabits grassy plains, and is noted for its extensive burrows and for heaping up miscellaneous articles at the mouth of its burrows. Called also biscacha, bizcacha, vischacha, vishatscha.
Voidness: The quality or state of being void; emptiness; vacuity; nullity; want of substantiality.
Veretillum: Any one of numerous species of club-shaped, compound Alcyonaria belonging to Veretillum and allied genera, of the tribe Pennatulacea.  The whole colony can move about as if it were a simple animal.
Vinic: Of or pertaining to wine; as, vinic alcohol.
Variolous: Of or pertaining to the smallpox; having pits, or sunken impressions, like those of the smallpox; variolar; variolic.
Vanward: Being on, or towards, the van, or front.
View: To see; to behold; especially, to look at with attention, or for the purpose of examining; to examine with the eye; to inspect; to explore.
Vireton: An arrow or bolt for a crossbow having feathers or brass placed at an angle with the shaft to make it spin in flying.
Vacuist: One who holds the doctrine that the space between the bodies of the universe, or the molecules and atoms of matter, is a vacuum; -- opposed to plenist.
Vermicular: Of or pertaining to a worm or worms; resembling a worm; shaped like a worm; especially, resembling the motion or track of a worm; as, the vermicular, or peristaltic, motion of the intestines.  See Peristaltic.
Vituline: Of or pertaining to a calf or veal.
Vivisect: To perform vivisection upon; to dissect alive.
Valeridine: A base, C10H19N, produced by heating valeric aldehyde with ammonia.  It is probably related to the conine alkaloids.
Vibrate: To move to and fro, or from side to side, as a pendulum, an elastic rod, or a stretched string, when disturbed from its position of rest; to swing; to oscillate.
Volta-electrometer: An instrument for the exact measurement of electric currents.
Valvelet: A little valve; a valvule; especially, one of the pieces which compose the outer covering of a pericarp.
Villus: One of the minute papillary processes on certain vascular membranes; a villosity; as, villi cover the lining of the small intestines of many animals and serve to increase the absorbing surface.
Vallets pills: Pills containing sulphate of iron and carbonate of sodium, mixed with saccharine matter; -- called also Vallet's mass.
Violet-tip: A very handsome American butterfly (Polygonia interrogationis).  Its wings are mottled with various shades of red and brown and have violet tips.
Vein: To form or mark with veins; to fill or cover with veins.
Vibratile: Adapted to, or used in, vibratory motion; having the power of vibrating; vibratory; as, the vibratile organs of insects.
Vitrescent: Capable of being formed into glass; tending to become glass.
Volante: A two-wheeled carriage formerly much used in Cuba. The body is in front of the axle; the driver rides on the horse.
Vogue: The way or fashion of people at any particular time; temporary mode, custom, or practice; popular reception for the time; -- used now generally in the phrase in vogue.
Variegate: To diversify in external appearance; to mark with different colors; to dapple; to streak; as, to variegate a floor with marble of different colors.
Verbarium: A game in word making.  See Logomachy, 2.
Vaticanist: One who strongly adheres to the papal authority; an ultramontanist.
Vansire: An ichneumon (Herpestes galera) native of Southern Africa and Madagascar. It is reddish brown or dark brown, grizzled with white. Called also vondsira, and marsh ichneumon.
Venturesome: Inclined to venture; not loth to run risk or danger; venturous; bold; daring; adventurous; as, a venturesome boy or act.
Volutation: A rolling of a body; a wallowing.
Virtuate: To make efficacious; to give virtue of efficacy.
Vaquero: One who has charge of cattle, horses, etc.; a herdsman; a cowboy.
Volar: Of or pertaining to the palm of the hand or the sole of the foot.
Vase: A vessel adapted for various domestic purposes, and anciently for sacrificial uses; especially, a vessel of antique or elegant pattern used for ornament; as, a porcelain vase; a gold vase; a Grecian vase.  See Illust. of Portland vase, under Portland.
Vengeance: Punishment inflicted in return for an injury or an offense; retribution; -- often, in a bad sense, passionate or unrestrained revenge.
Venire facias: A judicial writ or precept directed to the sheriff, requiring him to cause a certain number of qualified persons to appear in court at a specified time, to serve as jurors in said court.
Viscin: A clear, viscous, tasteless substance extracted from the mucilaginous sap of the mistletoe (Viscum album), holly, etc., and constituting an essential ingredient of birdlime.
Vast: A waste region; boundless space; immensity.
Vasodilator: A substance which causes dilation of blood vessels.
Valeric: Valerianic; specifically, designating any one of three metameric acids, of which the typical one (called also inactive valeric acid), C4H9CO2H, is obtained from valerian root and other sources, as a corrosive, mobile, oily liquid, having a strong acid taste, and an odor of old cheese.
vamoose: To depart quickly; to depart from.
Vinous: Of or pertaining to wine; having the qualities of wine; as, a vinous taste.
Valerin: A salt of valeric acid with glycerin, occurring in butter, dolphin oil, etc., and forming an oily liquid with a slightly unpleasant odor.
Voluntarism: Any theory which conceives will to be the dominant factor in experience or in the constitution of the world; -- contrasted with intellectualism.  Schopenhauer and Fichte are typical exponents of the two types of metaphysical voluntarism, Schopenhauer teaching that the evolution of the universe is the activity of a blind and irrational will, Fichte holding that the intelligent activity of the ego is the fundamental fact of reality.
Versicolor: Having various colors; changeable in color.
Vandyke beard: A trim, pointed beard, such as those often seen in pictures by Vandyke.
Vulpic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid obtained from a lichen (Cetraria vulpina) as a yellow or red crystalline substance which on decomposition yields pulvinic acid.
Vielle: An old stringed instrument played upon with a wheel; a hurdy-gurdy.
Venter: The belly; the abdomen; -- sometimes applied to any large cavity containing viscera.
Vanadium bronze: A yellow pigment consisting of a compound of vanadium.
Ventrad: Toward the ventral side; on the ventral side; ventrally; -- opposed to dorsad.
Ventral: Of, pertaining to, or situated near, the belly, or ventral side, of an animal or of one of its parts; hemal; abdominal; as, the ventral fin of a fish; the ventral root of a spinal nerve; -- opposed to dorsal.
Vulcanization: The act or process of imparting to caoutchouc, gutta-percha, or the like, greater elasticity, durability, or hardness by heating with sulphur under pressure.
Valedictory: A valedictory oration or address spoken at commencement in American colleges or seminaries by one of the graduating class, usually by the leading scholar.
Volleyed: Discharged with a sudden burst, or as if in a volley; as, volleyed thunder.
Van-courier: One sent in advance; an avant-courier; a precursor.
Vertebrarterial: Of or pertaining to a vertebra or vertebræ and an artery; -- said of the foramina in the transverse processes of cervical vertebræ and of the canal which they form for the vertebral artery and vein.
Volumenometer: An instrument for measuring the volume of a body, especially a solid, by means of the difference in tension caused by its presence and absence in a confined portion of air.
Veritas: The Bureau Veritas.  See under Bureau.
Vickers-Maxim automatic machine gun: An automatic machine gun in which the mechanism is worked by the recoil, assisted by the pressure of gases from the muzzle, which expand in a gas chamber against a disk attached to the end of the barrel, thus moving the latter to the rear with increased recoil, and against the front wall of the gas chamber, checking the recoil of the system.
Venatorial: Or or pertaining to hunting; venatic.
Vulcan powder: A dynamite composed of nitroglycerin (30 parts), sodium nitrate (52.5), charcoal (10.5), and sulphur (7), used in mining and blasting.
Vindictive: Disposed to revenge; prompted or characterized by revenge; revengeful.
Visioned: Having the power of seeing visions; inspired; also, seen in visions.
Vagabondage: The condition of a vagabond; a state or habit of wandering about in idleness; vagrancy.
Vital: A vital part; one of the vitals.
vitamin B6: a B vitamin that is essential for metabolism of amino acids and starch.
Versemonger: A writer of verses; especially, a writer of commonplace poetry; a poetaster; a rhymer; -- used humorously or in contempt.
Verruciform: Shaped like a wart or warts.
Vyce: A kind of clamp with gimlet points for holding a barrel head while the staves are being closed around it.
Vitiate: To make vicious, faulty, or imperfect; to render defective; to injure the substance or qualities of; to impair; to contaminate; to spoil; as, exaggeration vitiates a style of writing; sewer gas vitiates the air.
Variability: The quality or state of being variable; variableness.
Visitation: The act of visiting, or the state of being visited; access for inspection or examination.
Vicariate: Delegated office or power; vicarship; the office or oversight of a vicar.
Voracious: Greedy in eating; very hungry; eager to devour or swallow; ravenous; gluttonous; edacious; rapacious; as, a voracious man or appetite; a voracious gulf or whirlpool.
Vermicious: Of or pertaining to worms; wormy.
Vendors lien: An implied lien (that is, one not created by mortgage or other express agreement) given in equity to a vendor of lands for the unpaid purchase money.
Verdigris: To cover, or coat, with verdigris.
Vestal: A virgin consecrated to Vesta, and to the service of watching the sacred fire, which was to be perpetually kept burning upon her altar.
Vermicule: A small worm or insect larva; also, a wormlike body.
Verbal: A noun derived from a verb.
Vacuna: The goddess of rural leisure, to whom the husbandmen sacrificed at the close of the harvest.  She was especially honored by the Sabines.
Vire: An arrow, having a rotary motion, formerly used with the crossbow.  Cf. Vireton.
vitamin B complex: a mixture of water-soluble vitamins originally thought to be a single vitamin but now known to be a mixture of several compounds with vitaminic activity.
Vermiculation: The act or operation of moving in the manner of a worm; continuation of motion from one part to another; as, the vermiculation, or peristaltic motion, of the intestines.
Verners law: A statement, propounded by the Danish philologist Karl Verner in 1875, which explains certain apparent exceptions to Grimm's law by the original position of the accent.  Primitive Indo-European k, t, p, became first in Teutonic h, th, f, and appear without further change in old Teutonic, if the accent rested on the preceding syllable; but these sounds became voiced and produced g, d, b, if the accent was originally on a different syllable. Similarly s either remained unchanged, or it became z and later r. Example: Skt. saptā (accent on ultima), Gr. 'e`pta, Gothic sibun (seven). Examples in English are dead by the side of death, to rise and to rear.
Viatic: Of or pertaining to a journey or traveling.
Vociferation: The act of vociferating; violent outcry; vehement utterance of the voice.
Velours: One of many textile fabrics having a pile like that of velvet.
Vertex: A turning point; the principal or highest point; top; summit; crown; apex.
Vitric: Having the nature and qualities of glass; glasslike; -- distinguished from ceramic.
Virtuosity: The quality or state of being a virtuoso; in a bad sense, the character of one in whom mere artistic feeling or æsthetic cultivation takes the place of religious character; sentimentalism.
Variolite: A kind of diorite or diabase containing imbedded whitish spherules, which give the rock a spotted appearance.
Vesicouterine: Of or pertaining to the bladder and the uterus.
Vole: Any one of numerous species of micelike rodents belonging to Arvicola and allied genera of the subfamily Arvicolinæ. They have a thick head, short ears, and a short hairy tail.
Violence: To assault; to injure; also, to bring by violence; to compel.
Violator: One who violates; an infringer; a profaner; a ravisher.
Villa: A country seat; a country or suburban residence of some pretensions to elegance.
Verily: In very truth; beyond doubt or question; in fact; certainly.
Ventilator: A contrivance for effecting ventilation; especially, a contrivance or machine for drawing off or expelling foul or stagnant air from any place or apartment, or for introducing that which is fresh and pure.
Visualize: To form a mental image of something not present before the eye at the time.
Veratralbine: A yellowish amorphous alkaloid extracted from the rootstock of Veratrum album.
Volumeter: An instrument for measuring the volumes of gases or liquids by introducing them into a vessel of known capacity.
vitamin B2: a B vitamin that prevents skin lesions and weight loss.
vitamin B1: a B vitamin (C12H17N4OS)Cl that prevents beriberi and maintains appetite and growth.  Same as thiamine.
Villatic: Of or pertaining to a farm or a village; rural.
Virescence: The act or state of becoming green through the formation of chlorophyll.
Voyager: One who voyages; one who sails or passes by sea or water.
Vigorous: Possessing vigor; full of physical or mental strength or active force; strong; lusty; robust; as, a vigorous youth; a vigorous plant.
Vassal: To treat as a vassal; to subject to control; to enslave.
Varietal: Of or pertaining to a variety; characterizing a variety; constituting a variety, in distinction from an individual or species.
Verbarian: One who coins words; a neologist.
Varietas: A variety; -- used in giving scientific names, and often abbreviated to var.
Virtue: Manly strength or courage; bravery; daring; spirit; valor.
Vouchsafement: The act of vouchsafing, or that which is vouchsafed; a gift or grant in condescension.
vitamin Bc: a B vitamin that is essential for cell growth and reproduction.  Also called folic acid
Veined: Full of veins; streaked; variegated; as, veined marble.
Vestlet: Any one of several species of actinians belonging to the genus Cerianthus.  These animals have a long, smooth body tapering to the base, and two separate circles of tentacles around the mouth.  They form a tough, flexible, feltlike tube with a smooth internal lining, in which they dwell, whence the name.
Vowelize: To give the quality, sound, or office of a vowel to.
Vendition: The act of vending, or selling; sale.
Voider: One who, or that which, voids, &unr_;mpties, vacates, or annuls.
Vesper: Of or pertaining to the evening, or to the service of vespers; as, a vesper hymn; vesper bells.
Viviparity: The quality or condition of being viviparous.
Virose: Having a nauseous odor; fetid; poisonous.
Volkslied: A popular song, or national air.
Volvox: A genus of minute, pale-green, globular, organisms, about one fiftieth of an inch in diameter, found rolling through water, the motion being produced by minute colorless cilia. It has been considered as belonging to the flagellate Infusoria, but is now referred to the vegetable kingdom, and each globule is considered a colony of many individuals. The commonest species is Volvox globator, often called globe animalcule.
Vortiginous: Moving rapidly round a center; vortical.
Veto: To prohibit; to negative; also, to refuse assent to, as a legislative bill, and thus prevent its enactment; as, to veto an appropriation bill.
Verbenaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order (Verbenaceæ) of gamopetalous plants of which Verbena is the type. The order includes also the black and white mangroves, and many plants noted for medicinal use or for beauty of bloom.
Vicissitudinous: Full of, or subject to, changes.
Virial: A certain function relating to a system of forces and their points of application, -- first used by Clausius in the investigation of problems in molecular physics.
Varec: The calcined ashes of any coarse seaweed used for the manufacture of soda and iodine; also, the seaweed itself; fucus; wrack.
Victorium: A probable chemical element discovered by Sir William Crookes in 1898. Its nitrate is obtained byy practical decomposition and crystallization of yttrium nitrate. At. wt., about 117.
Ventriloquism: The act, art, or practice of speaking in such a manner that the voice appears to come, not from the person speaking, but from some other source, as from a dummy held by the ventriloquist, from the opposite side of the room, from the cellar, etc.
Virtuality: The quality or state of being virtual.
Ventriloquist: One who practices, or is skilled in, ventriloquism.
Vincetoxin: A glucoside extracted from the root of the white swallowwort (Vincetoxicum officinale, a plant of the Asclepias family) as a bitter yellow amorphous substance; -- called also asclepiadin, and cynanchin.
Valuable: A precious possession; a thing of value, especially a small thing, as an article of jewelry; -- used mostly in the plural.
Vaporizable: Capable of being vaporized, or converted into vapor.
Valuably: So as to be of value.
Viscount: An officer who formerly supplied the place of the count, or earl; the sheriff of the county.
Vari: The ringtailed lemur (Lemur catta) of Madagascar. Its long tail is annulated with black and white.
Votive: Given by vow, or in fulfillment of a vow; consecrated by a vow; devoted; as, votive offerings; a votive tablet.
Valencia: A kind of woven fabric for waistcoats, having the weft of wool and the warp of silk or cotton.
Voyageur: A traveler; -- applied in Canada to a man employed by the fur companies in transporting goods by the rivers and across the land, to and from the remote stations in the Northwest.
Viviparousness: The quality of being viviparous; viviparity.
Vugg: A cavity in a lode; -- called also vogle.
Vedic: Of or pertaining to the Vedas or one of the Vedas.
Visceroskeletal: Of or pertaining to the framework, or skeleton, or skeleton, of the viscera; as, the visceroskeletal system of muscles.
Viscosity: The quality or state of being viscous.
Vinyl: The hypothetical radical C2H3, regarded as the characteristic residue of ethylene and that related series of unsaturated hydrocarbons with which the allyl compounds are homologous.
Vowel: Of or pertaining to a vowel; vocal.
Veratrol: A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the decomposition of veratric acid, and constituting the dimethyl ether of pyrocatechin.
Verbify: To make into a verb; to use as a verb; to verbalize.
Victuals: Food for human beings, esp. when it is cooked or prepared for the table; that which supports human life; provisions; sustenance; meat; viands.
Virgouleuse: An old French variety of pear, of little value.
Vacate: To make vacant; to leave empty; to cease from filling or occupying; as, it was resolved by Parliament that James had vacated the throne of England; the tenant vacated the house.
Volunteers of America: A religious and philanthropic organization, similar to the Salvation Army, founded (1896) by Commander and Mrs. Ballington Booth.
Vin ordinaire: A cheap claret, used as a table wine in France.
Vellicate: To move spasmodically; to twitch; as, a nerve vellicates.
Vaccination: The act, art, or practice of vaccinating, or inoculating with the cowpox, in order to prevent or mitigate an attack of smallpox.  Cf. Inoculation.
Velleity: The lowest degree of desire; imperfect or incomplete volition.
Viripotent: Developed in manhood; hence, able to beget; marriageable.
Vaccinal: Of or pertaining to vaccinia or vaccination.
Vauquelinite: Chromate of copper and lead, of various shades of green.
Versionist: One who makes or favors a version; a translator.
Vinatico: Madeira mahogany; the coarse, dark-colored wood of the Persea Indica.
Vulpine: Of or pertaining to the fox; resembling the fox; foxy; cunning; crafty; artful.
Vulcan: The god of fire, who presided over the working of metals; -- answering to the Greek Hephæstus.
vives: A disease of brute animals, especially of horses, seated in the glands under the ear, where a tumor is formed which sometimes ends in suppuration.
Venosity: The quality or state of being venous.
Vitrage: A curtain of light and translucent material intended to be secured directly to the woodwork of a French casement window or a glazed door.
Vermiculite: A group of minerals having, a micaceous structure. They are hydrous silicates, derived generally from the alteration of some kind of mica. So called because the scales, when heated, open out into wormlike forms.
Vertiginous: Turning round; whirling; rotary; revolving; as, a vertiginous motion.
Vaporiform: Existing in a vaporous form or state; as, steam is a vaporiform substance.
Vestibuled train: Same as Vestibule  train, under Vestibule.
Vulviform: Like a cleft with projecting edges.
Vibroscope: An instrument for observing or tracing vibrations.
Vaginant: Serving to invest, or sheathe; sheathing.
Valuator: One who assesses, or sets a value on, anything; an appraiser.
Vaginitis: Inflammation of the vagina, or the genital canal, usually of its mucous lining membrane.
Visibility: The quality or state of being visible.
Vicontiel: Of or pertaining to the viscount or sheriff of a county.
Vested interest: a special personal interest, usually financial, in an existing system, law, or institution, which hinders a person from making objective decisions regarding that system, law, or institution.  A vested interest may be one which benefits a relative, or, in an extended sense, one which defends a person's own reputation or previously expressed views.
Valeryl: The hypothetical radical C5H9O, regarded as the essential nucleus of certain valeric acid derivatives.
Ventilative: Of or pertaining to ventilation; adapted to secure ventilation; ventilating; as, ventilative apparatus.
Viceman: A smith who works at the vice instead of at the anvil.
Venetian: A native or inhabitant of Venice.
Viander: A feeder; an eater; also, one who provides viands, or food; a host.
Vulture: Any one of numerous species of rapacious birds belonging to Vultur, Cathartes, Catharista, and various other genera of the family Vulturidæ.
Verdure: Green; greenness; freshness of vegetation; as, the verdure of the meadows in June.
Voltairean: Of or relating to Voltaire, the French author.
Vertebrally: At or within a vertebra or vertebræ; -- distinguished from interverterbrally.
Voodoo economics: an economic hypothesis, proposed by President Ronald Regan, that large cuts in tax rates would so stimulate the economy that the tax revenue on the increases in business and personal income would offset the anticipated tax revenue losses, so that such tax cuts would not increasing the federal budget deficit.  Its believers do not consider the actual massive deficit increases subsequent to the 1982-83 tax cut as being caused by the tax cut itself, but by other governmental policies.  This hypothesis was graphically illustrated by the Laffer curve.
Velvetleaf: A name given to several plants which have soft, velvety leaves, as the Abutilon Avicennæ, the Cissampelos Pareira, and the Lavatera arborea, and even the common mullein.
Vivisectionist: One who practices or advocates vivisection; a vivisector.
Vadimony: A bond or pledge for appearance before a judge on a certain day.
Vermiculose: Containing, or full of, worms; resembling worms.
Vaultage: Vaulted work; also, a vaulted place; an arched cellar.
Vamper: To swagger; to make an ostentatious show.
Violantin: A complex nitrogenous substance, produced as a yellow crystalline substance, and regarded as a complex derivative of barbituric acid.
Vetch: Any leguminous plant of the genus Vicia, some species of which are valuable for fodder. The common species is Vicia sativa.
Verifier: One who, or that which, verifies.
Vivificative: Able or tending to vivify, animate, or give life; vivifying.
Volt amp\u00e8re: A unit of electric measurement equal to the product of a volt and an ampere. For direct current it is a measure of power and is the same as a watt; for alternating current it is a measure of apparent power.
Vitelline: Of or pertaining to the yolk of eggs; as, the vitelline membrane, a smooth, transparent membrane surrounding the vitellus.
Vivace: Brisk; vivacious; with spirit; -- a direction to perform a passage in a brisk and lively manner.
Vulgarization: The act or process of making vulgar, or common.
Visite: A light cape or short cloak of silk or lace worn by women in summer.
Vanquish: A disease in sheep, in which they pine away.
Vulnerableness: The quality or state of being vulnerable; vulnerability.
Violaquercitrin: A yellow crystalline glucoside obtained from the pansy (Viola tricolor), and decomposing into glucose and quercitrin.
Veer: To direct to a different course; to turn; to wear; as, to veer, or wear, a vessel.
Vaginismus: A painful spasmodic contraction of the vagina, often rendering copulation impossible.
Vidonia: A dry white wine, of a tart flavor, produced in Teneriffe; -- called also Teneriffe.
Vedantist: One versed in the doctrines of the Vedantas.
Vernacular: The vernacular language; one's mother tongue; often, the common forms of expression in a particular locality, opposed to literary or learned forms.
Vulvo-uterine: Pertaining both to the vulva and the uterus.
Vincibility: The quality or state of being vincible, vincibleness.
Vedantic: Of or pertaining to the Vedas.
Vesicate: To raise little bladders or blisters upon; to inflame and separate the cuticle of; to blister.
Varnisher: One who varnishes; one whose occupation is to varnish.
Vicegerent: An officer who is deputed by a superior, or by proper authority, to exercise the powers of another; a lieutenant; a vicar.
Valet: A male waiting servant; a servant who attends on a gentleman's person; a body servant.
Virelay: An ancient French song, or short poem, wholly in two rhymes, and composed in short lines, with a refrain.
Vasomotor: Causing movement in the walls of vessels; as, the vasomotor mechanisms; the vasomotor nerves, a system of nerves distributed over the muscular coats of the blood vessels.
Verberation: The act of verberating; a beating or striking.
Vimen: A long, slender, flexible shoot or branch.
Ventro-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the abdomen; also, connection with, relation to, or direction toward, the ventral side; as, ventrolateral; ventro-inguinal.
Vendetta: A blood feud; private revenge for the murder of a kinsman.
Versification: The act, art, or practice, of versifying, or making verses; the construction of poetry; metrical composition.
Vinegary: Having the nature of vinegar; sour; unamiable.
Voltzite: An oxysulphide of lead occurring in implanted spherical globules of a yellowish or brownish color; -- called also voltzine.
Vicar: One deputed or authorized to perform the functions of another; a substitute in office; a deputy.
Viperoid: Like or pertaining to the vipers.
Violent: To be violent; to act violently.
Van: To fan, or to cleanse by fanning; to winnow.
Velveret: A kind of velvet having cotton back.
Vexatious: Causing vexation; agitating; afflictive; annoying; as, a vexatious controversy; a vexatious neighbor.
Vaimure: An outer, or exterior, wall.  See Vauntmure.
Vernine: An alkaloid extracted from the shoots of the vetch, red clover, etc., as a white crystalline substance.
Volap\u00fckist: One who is conversant with, or who favors adoption of, Volapük.
Valorization: Act or process of attempting to give an arbitrary market value or price to a commodity by governmental interference, as by maintaining a purchasing fund, making loans to producers to enable them to hold their products, etc.; -- used chiefly of such action by Brazil.
Vap: That which is vapid, insipid, or lifeless; especially, the lifeless part of liquor or wine.
Verdant: Covered with growing plants or grass; green; fresh; flourishing; as, verdant fields; a verdant lawn.
Vat: To put or transfer into a vat.
Varuna: The god of the waters; the Indian Neptune. He is regarded as regent of the west, and lord of punishment, and is represented as riding on a sea monster, holding in his hand a snaky cord or noose with which to bind offenders, under water.
Vapor galvanizing: A process for coating metal (usually iron or steel) surfaces with zinc by exposing them to the vapor of zinc instead of, as in ordinary galvanizing, to molten zinc; -- called also Sherardizing. Vapor galvanizing is accomplished by heating the articles to be galvanized together with zinc dust in an air tight receptacle to a temperature of about 600° F., which is 188° below the melting point of zinc, or by exposing the articles to vapor from molten zinc in a separate receptacle, using hydrogen or other reducing gas to prevent oxidation.
viverrine: Of or pertaining to the Viverridæ, or Civet family.
Vivacity: The quality or state of being vivacious.
Vetchling: Any small leguminous plant of the genus Lathyrus, especially Lathyrus Nissolia.
Voiding: Receiving what is ejected or voided.
Vigintivirate: The office of the vigintiviri, a body of officers of government consisting of twenty men; also, the vigintiviri.
Venturer: One who ventures, or puts to hazard; an adventurer.
Valeritrine: A base, C15H27N, produced together with valeridine, which it resembles.
Vesta: One of the great divinities of the ancient Romans, identical with the Greek Hestia. She was a virgin, and the goddess of the hearth; hence, also, of the fire on it, and the family round it.
Vitrite: A kind of glass which is very hard and difficult to fuse, used as an insulator in electrical lamps and other apparatus.
Vehicled: Conveyed in a vehicle; furnished with a vehicle.
Vulneration: The act of wounding, or the state of being wounded.
Veiling: A veil; a thin covering; also, material for making veils.
Vain: Vanity; emptiness; -- now used only in the phrase in vain.
Vair: The skin of the squirrel, much used in the fourteenth century as fur for garments, and frequently mentioned by writers of that period in describing the costly dresses of kings, nobles, and prelates.  It is represented in heraldry by a series of small shields placed close together, and alternately white and blue.
Vallum: A rampart; a wall, as in a fortification.
Vibraculum: One of the movable, slender, spinelike organs or parts with which certain bryozoans are furnished. They are regarded as specially modified zooids, of nearly the same nature as Avicularia.
Vicontiels: Things belonging to the sheriff; especially, farms (called also vicontiel rents) for which the sheriff used to pay rent to the king.
Vacuole: A small air cell, or globular space, in the interior of organic cells, either containing air, or a pellucid watery liquid, or some special chemical secretions of the cell protoplasm.
Vaporimeter: An instrument for measuring the volume or the tension of any vapor; specifically, an instrument of this sort used as an alcoholometer in testing spirituous liquors.
Vaccinate: To inoculate with the cowpox by means of a virus, called vaccine, taken either directly or indirectly from cows; now, generally, to administer (by injection or otherwise) any vaccine with the objective of rendering the recipient immune to an infectious disease.  One who has been thus immunized by vaccination is said to be vaccinated against a particular disease.  One may be thus immunized (vaccinated) also by oral ingestion or inhalation of a vaccine.
Vicarship: The office or dignity of a vicar.
Verriculate: Having thickset tufts of parallel hairs, bristles, or branches.
Variscite: An apple-green mineral occurring in reniform masses. It is a hydrous phosphate of alumina.
Vara: A Spanish measure of length equal to about one yard. The vara now in use equals 33.385 inches.
Volcanization: The act of volcanizing, or the state of being volcanized; the process of undergoing volcanic heat, and being affected by it.
Valvata: A genus of small spiral fresh-water gastropods having an operculum.
Victualing: Of or pertaining to victuals, or provisions; supplying provisions; as, a victualing ship.
Valiance: The quality or state of being valiant; bravery; valor.
Versability: The quality or state of being versable.
Verine: An alkaloid obtained as a yellow amorphous substance by the decomposition of veratrine.
Variformed: Formed with different shapes; having various forms; variform.
Venerate: To regard with reverential respect; to honor with mingled respect and awe; to reverence; to revere; as, we venerate parents and elders.
Vulpinite: A scaly granular variety of anhydrite of a grayish white color, used for ornamental purposes.
Veinless: Having no veins; as, a veinless leaf.
Variegation: The act of variegating or diversifying, or the state of being diversified, by different colors; diversity of colors.
Volition: The act of willing or choosing; the act of forming a purpose; the exercise of the will.
Virgularian: Any one of numerous species of long, slender Alcyonaria belonging to Virgularia and allied genera of the family Virgularidæ. These corals are allied to the sea-pens, but have a long rodlike rhachis inclosing a slender, round or square, calcareous axis. The polyps are arranged in transverse rows or clusters along each side of the rhachis.
Veneration: The act of venerating, or the state of being venerated; the highest degree of respect and reverence; respect mingled with awe; a feeling or sentiment excited by the dignity, wisdom, or superiority of a person, by sacredness of character, by consecration to sacred services, or by hallowed associations.
Velveting: The fine shag or nap of velvet; a piece of velvet; velvet goods.
Venefice: The act or practice of poisoning.
Vexillation: A company of troops under one vexillum.
Veda: The ancient sacred literature of the Hindus; also, one of the four collections, called Rig-Veda, Yajur-Veda, Sama-Veda, and Atharva-Veda, constituting the most ancient portions of that literature.
Vined: Having leaves like those of the vine; ornamented with vine leaves.
Virtuoso: One devoted to virtu; one skilled in the fine arts, in antiquities, and the like; a collector or ardent admirer of curiosities, etc.
Versicular: Of or pertaining to verses; designating distinct divisions of a writing.
Vichy water: A mineral water found at Vichy, France.  It is essentially an effervescent aqueous solution of sodium, calcium, and magnesium carbonates, with sodium and potassium chlorides; also, by extension, any artificial or natural water resembling in composition the Vichy water proper.  Called also, colloquially, Vichy.
Vinaceous: Belonging to, or like, wine or grapes.
Volcanic neck: A column of igneous rock formed by congelation of lava in the conduit of a volcano and later exposed by the removal of surrounding rocks.
Vincibleness: The quality or state of being vincible.
Verys night signals: A system of signaling in which balls of red and green fire are fired from a pistol, the arrangement in groups denoting numbers having a code significance.  The pistol used to fire the signal flare is called a Very pistol.
Voluntarily: In a voluntary manner; of one's own will; spontaneously.
Versify: To relate or describe in verse; to compose in verse.
Vendue: A public sale of anything, by outcry, to the highest bidder; an auction.
Viceroy: The governor of a country or province who rules in the name of the sovereign with regal authority, as the king's substitute; as, the viceroy of India.
Verticality: The quality or state of being vertical; verticalness.
Vibrograph: An instrument to observe and record vibrations.
Versual: Of or pertaining to a verse.
Valetudinarianism: The condition of a valetudinarian; a state of feeble health; infirmity.
Viand: An article of food; provisions; food; victuals; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Vesuvianite: A mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals, and also massive, of a brown to green color, rarely sulphur yellow and blue. It is a silicate of alumina and lime with some iron magnesia, and is common at Vesuvius. Also called idocrase.
Vitreousness: The quality or state of being vitreous.
Vim: Power; force; energy; spirit; activity; vigor.
Vagabondize: To play the vagabond; to wander about in idleness.
Viny: Of or pertaining to vines; producing, or abounding in, vines.
Visible: Perceivable by the eye; capable of being seen; perceptible; in view; as, a visible star; the least spot is visible on white paper.
Vociferous: Making a loud outcry; clamorous; noisy; as, vociferous heralds.
Vairy: Charged with vair; variegated with shield-shaped figures. See Vair.
Vitriolated: Changed into a vitriol or a sulphate, or subjected to the action of sulphuric acid or of a sulphate; as, vitriolated potash, i. e., potassium sulphate.
Venose: Having numerous or conspicuous veins; veiny; as, a venose frond.
Viscid: Sticking or adhering, and having a ropy or glutinous consistency; viscous; glutinous; sticky; tenacious; clammy; as, turpentine, tar, gums, etc., are more or less viscid.
Vinegar: To convert into vinegar; to make like vinegar; to render sour or sharp.
Verbalist: A literal adherent to, or a minute critic of, words; a literalist.
Vivipara: An artificial division of vertebrates including those that produce their young alive; -- opposed to Ovipara.
Vincible: Capable of being overcome or subdued; conquerable.
Verbalism: Something expressed verbally; a verbal remark or expression.
Vagantes: A tribe of spiders, comprising some of those which take their prey in a web, but which also frequently run with agility, and chase and seize their prey.
Vigesimo-quarto: A book composed of sheets each of which is folded into twenty-four leaves; hence, indicating more or less definitely a size of book so made; -- usually written 24mo, or 24°.
Volley ball: A game played by volleying a large inflated ball with the hands over a net 7 ft. 6 in. high.
Vitilitigate: To contend in law litigiously or cavilously.
Virgate: A yardland, or measure of land varying from fifteen to forty acres.
Vulcanology: The science which treats of phenomena due to plutonic action, as in volcanoes, hot springs, etc.
Viticulture: The cultivation of the vine; grape growing.
Viatecture: The art of making roads or ways for traveling, including the construction of bridges, canals, viaducts, etc.
Vomit: To throw up; to eject from the stomach through the mouth; to disgorge; to puke; to spew out; -- often followed by up or out.
Valenciennes lace: A rich kind of lace made at Valenciennes, in France. Each piece is made throughout, ground and pattern, by the same person and with the same thread, the pattern being worked in the net.
Valuation: The act of valuing, or of estimating value or worth; the act of setting a price; estimation; appraisement; as, a valuation of lands for the purpose of taxation.
Valerianic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, valerian root; specifically, designating an acid which is usually called valeric acid.
Vertebro-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, a vertebra, vertebræ, or the vertebral column; as in vertebrocostal.
Viridescence: Quality or state of being viridescent.
