Vent: To let out at a vent, or small aperture; to give passage or outlet to.
Vakeel: A native attorney or agent; also, an ambassador.
Volow: To baptize; -- used in contempt by the Reformers.
Victorian: Of or pertaining to the reign of Queen Victoria of England; as, the Victorian poets.
Vatical: Of or pertaining to a prophet; prophetical.
Vatican: A magnificent assemblage of buildings at Rome, near the church of St. Peter, including the pope's palace, a museum, a library, a famous chapel, etc.
Vestured: Covered with vesture or garments; clothed; enveloped.
Ventail: That part of a helmet which is intended for the admission of air, -- sometimes in the visor.
Vituperator: One who vituperates, or censures abusively.
Vernonin: A glucoside extracted from the root of a South African plant of the genus Vernonia, as a deliquescent powder, and used as a mild heart tonic.
Vibratory: Consisting in, or causing, vibration, or oscillation; vibrating; as, a vibratory motion; a vibratory power.
Verisimilar: Having the appearance of truth; probable; likely.
Vishnu: A divinity of the modern Hindu trimurti, or trinity. He is regarded as the preserver, while Brahma is the creator, and Siva the destroyer of the creation.
Vaccinium: A genus of ericaceous shrubs including the various kinds of blueberries and the true cranberries.
Varnishing: The act of laying on varnish; also, materials for varnish.
Vocalness: The quality of being vocal; vocality.
Vestige: The mark of the foot left on the earth; a track or footstep; a trace; a sign; hence, a faint mark or visible sign left by something which is lost, or has perished, or is no longer present; remains; as, the vestiges of ancient magnificence in Palmyra; vestiges of former population.
Vivandi\u00e8re: In Continental armies, especially in the French army, a woman accompanying a regiment, who sells provisions and liquor to the soldiers; a female sutler.
Vinaigrette: A sauce, made of vinegar, oil, and other ingredients, -- used esp. for cold meats.
Victimate: To make a victim of; to sacrifice; to immolate.
Varvel: In falconry, one of the rings secured to the ends of the jesses.
Volplane: To glide in a flying machine.
Vendace: A European lake whitefish (Coregonus Willughbii, or Coregonus Vandesius) native of certain lakes in Scotland and England.  It is regarded as a delicate food fish.  Called also vendis.
Vow-fellow: One bound by the same vow as another.
Veronese: Of or pertaining to Verona, in Italy.
Vanish: The brief terminal part of a vowel or vocal element, differing more or less in quality from the main part; as, a as in ale ordinarily ends with a vanish of i as in ill, o as in old with a vanish of oo as in foot.
Vicenary: Of or pertaining to twenty; consisting of twenty.
Vigorite: An explosive containing nitroglycerin. It is used in blasting.
Vesiculose: Bladdery; vesicular; vesiculate; composed of vesicles; covered with vesicles; as, a vesiculose shell.
Viraginity: The qualities or characteristics of a virago.
vitamin A2: dehydroretinol (C20H28O), one of the substances also called vitamin A.  It has about 40% of the bioactivity of vitamin A1.
vitamin A1: retinol (C20H30O), one of the substances also called vitamin A.  It is also called more specifically vitamin A alcohol.  It is a required factor for human nutrition.  The USP unit of activity is equal to 0.30 micrograms of retinol.
Vocal: Of or pertaining to the voice or speech; having voice; endowed with utterance; full of voice, or voices.
Vaporation: The act or process of converting into vapor, or of passing off in vapor; evaporation.
Venture: To expose to hazard; to risk; to hazard; as, to venture one's person in a balloon.
Valence: The degree of combining power of an atom (or radical) as shown by the number of atoms of hydrogen (or of other monads, as chlorine, sodium, etc.) with which it will combine, or for which it can be substituted, or with which it can be compared; thus, an atom of hydrogen is a monad, and has a valence of one; the atoms of oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon are respectively dyads, triads, and tetrads, and have a valence respectively of two, three, and four.
Vainglorious: Feeling or indicating vainglory; elated by vanity; boastful.
Voltameter: An instrument for measuring the voltaic electricity passing through it, by its effect in decomposing water or some other chemical compound acting as an electrolyte.
Vestales: A group of butterflies including those known as virgins, or gossamer-winged butterflies.
Viscountship: The quality, rank, or office of a viscount.
Voltaism: That form of electricity which is developed by the chemical action between metals and different liquids; voltaic electricity; also, the science which treats of this form of electricity; -- called also galvanism, from Galvani, on account of his experiments showing the remarkable influence of this agent on animals.
Vestiarian: Of or pertaining to a vestiary or vestments.
Visive: Of or pertaining to the sight; visual.
Valinch: A tube for drawing liquors from a cask by the bunghole.
Victorious: Of or pertaining to victory, or a victor; being a victor; bringing or causing a victory; conquering; winning; triumphant; as, a victorious general; victorious troops; a victorious day.
Verticillate: Arranged in a transverse whorl or whorls like the rays of a wheel; as, verticillate leaves of a plant; a verticillate shell.
Vestigial: Of or pertaining to a vestige or remnant; like a vestige.
Vellon: A word occurring in the phrase real vellon. See the Note under 1st Real.
Virginia: One of the States of the United States of America.
Vicinage: The place or places adjoining or near; neighborhood; vicinity; as, a jury must be of the vicinage.
Volti: Turn, that is, turn over the leaf.
Vitriolic: Of or pertaining to vitriol; derived from, or resembling, vitriol; vitriolous; as, a vitriolic taste.  Cf. Vitriol.
Versicle: A little verse; especially, a short verse or text said or sung in public worship by the priest or minister, and followed by a response from the people.
Viaticum: An allowance for traveling expenses made to those who were sent into the provinces to exercise any office or perform any service.
Vulnerability: The quality or state of being vulnerable; vulnerableness.
Vega: An open tract of ground; a plain, esp. one which is moist and fertile, as those used for tobacco fields.
Vituperable: Liable to, or deserving, vituperation, or severe censure.
Vacuolation: Formation into, or multiplication of, vacuoles.
Vortical: Of or pertaining to a vortex or vortexes; resembling a vortex in form or motion; whirling; as, a vortical motion.
Verbalization: The act of verbalizing, or the state of being verbalized.
Vivianite: A hydrous phosphate of iron of a blue to green color, growing darker on exposure.  It occurs in monoclinic crystals, also fibrous, massive, and earthy.
Vestment: A covering or garment; some part of clothing or dress
Vintry: A place where wine is sold.
Venite: The 95th Psalm, which is said or sung regularly in the public worship of many churches. Also, a musical composition adapted to this Psalm.
Vagarious: Given to, or characterized by, vagaries; capricious; whimsical; crochety.
Varicosity: The quality or state of being varicose.
Value: The property or aggregate properties of a thing by which it is rendered useful or desirable, or the degree of such property or sum of properties; worth; excellence; utility; importance.
Variance: The quality or state of being variant; change of condition; variation.
Veniality: The quality or state of being venial; venialness.
Vainness: The quality or state of being vain.
Vignetter: A device used by photographers in printing vignettes, consisting of a screen of paper or glass with a central aperture the edges of which become opaque by insensible gradations.
Vineyard: An inclosure or yard for grapevines; a plantation of vines producing grapes.
vamp: To seduce (a man) sexually for purpose of exploitation.
Venom: To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison.
Venantes: The hunting spiders, which run after, or leap upon, their prey.
Vasoconstrictor: A substance which causes constriction of the blood vessels.  Such substances are used in medicine to raise abnormally low blood pressure.
Valerylene: A liquid hydrocarbon, C5H8; -- called also pentine.
Vermiculate: Wormlike in shape; covered with wormlike elevations; marked with irregular fine lines of color, or with irregular wavy impressed lines like worm tracks; as, a vermiculate nut.
Vauntmure: A false wall; a work raised in front of the main wall.
Viscous: Adhesive or sticky, and having a ropy or glutinous consistency; viscid; glutinous; clammy; tenacious; as, a viscous juice.
Vermiform: Resembling a worm in form or motions; vermicular; as, the vermiform process of the cerebellum.
Vapor pressure: The pressure or tension of a confined body of vapor of a chemical substance in equilibrium with the solid or liquid form of the substance.  The pressure of a given saturated vapor is a function of the temperature only, and may be measured by introducing a small quantity of the substance into a barometer and noting the depression of the column of mercury.
Viva: Lit., (long) live; -- an exclamation expressing good will, well wishing, etc.
vamose: To vamoose; -- an older spelling and pronunciation variant.
Victory: The defeat of an enemy in battle, or of an antagonist in any contest; a gaining of the superiority in any struggle or competition; conquest; triumph; -- the opposite of defeat.
Violable: Capable of being violated, broken, or injured.
Viniculture: The cultivation of the vine, esp. for making wine; viticulture.
Violet: Dark blue, inclining to red; bluish purple; having a color produced by red and blue combined.
Vecture: The act of carrying; conveyance; carriage.
Vitrina: A genus of terrestrial gastropods, having transparent, very thin, and delicate shells, -- whence the name.
Vendee: The person to whom a thing is vended, or sold; -- the correlative of vendor.
Vitrine: A glass show case for displaying fine wares, specimens, etc.
Vainglory: Excessive vanity excited by one's own performances; empty pride; undue elation of mind; vain show; boastfulness.
Vender: One who vends; one who transfers the exclusive right of possessing a thing, either his own, or that of another as his agent, for a price or pecuniary equivalent; a seller; a vendor.
Velitation: A dispute or contest; a slight contest; a skirmish.
Vedro: A Russian liquid measure, equal to 3.249 gallons of U. S. standard measure, or 2.706 imperial gallons.
Vaticide: The murder, or the murderer, of a prophet.
Vignette: To make, as an engraving or a photograph, with a border or edge insensibly fading away.
Vulturism: The quality or state of being like a vulture; rapaciousness.
Viewiness: The quality or state of being viewy, or of having unpractical views.
Venal: Capable of being bought or obtained for money or other valuable consideration; made matter of trade or barter; held for sale; salable; mercenary; purchasable; hireling; as, venal services.
Vitre-o-electic: Containing or exhibiting positive, or vitreous, electricity.
Vaisya: The third of the four great original castes among the Hindus, now either extinct or partially represented by the mercantile class of Banyas. See the Note under Caste, 1.
Volap\u00fck: Literally, world's speech; the name of an artificial language invented by Johan Martin Schleyer, of Constance, Switzerland, about 1879.
Virgilian: Of or pertaining to Virgil, the Roman poet; resembling the style of Virgil.
Volborthite: A mineral occurring in small six-sided tabular crystals of a green or yellow color. It is a hydrous vanadate of copper and lime.
Velivolant: Flying with sails; passing under full sail.
Volta-electric: Of or pertaining to voltaic electricity, or voltaism.
Violation: The act of violating, treating with violence, or injuring; the state of being violated.
Vivisection: The dissection of an animal while alive, for the purpose of making physiological investigations.
Vacatur: An order of court by which a proceeding is set aside or annulled.
Viraginian: Of or pertaining to a virago; having the qualities of a virago.
Viperoidea: A division of serpents which includes the true vipers of the Old World and the rattlesnakes and moccasin snakes of America; -- called also Viperina.
Victual: To supply with provisions for subsistence; to provide with food; to store with sustenance; as, to victual an army; to victual a ship.
Viola: An instrument in form and use resembling the violin, but larger, and a fifth lower in compass.
Vartabed: A doctor or teacher in the Armenian church. Members of this order of ecclesiastics frequently have charge of dioceses, with episcopal functions.
Vesicovaginal: Of or pertaining to the bladder and the vagina.
Valise: A small sack or case, usually of leather, but sometimes of other material, for containing the clothes, toilet articles, etc., of a traveler; a traveling bag; a portmanteau.
Velocipede: A light road carriage propelled by the feet of the rider. Originally it was propelled by striking the tips of the toes on the roadway, but commonly now by the action of the feet on a pedal or pedals connected with the axle of one or more of the wheels, and causing their revolution. They are made in many forms, with two, three, or four wheels. See Bicycle, and Tricycle.
Vermicelli: The flour of a hard and small-grained wheat made into dough, and forced through small cylinders or pipes till it takes a slender, wormlike form, whence the Italian name. When the paste is made in larger tubes, it is called macaroni.
Ventriculus: One of the stomachs of certain insects.
Valerianaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, plants of a natural order (Valerianaceæ) of which the valerian is the type. The order includes also the corn salads and the oriental spikenard.
Vermination: The generation or breeding of vermin.
Vaporable: Capable of being converted into vapor by the agency of heat; vaporizable.
Vocally: In a vocal manner; with voice; orally; with audible sound.
Venomous: Full of venom; noxious to animal life; poisonous; as, the bite of a serpent may be venomous.
Velvety: Made of velvet, or like velvet; soft; smooth; delicate.
Vilification: The act of vilifying or defaming; abuse.
Virago: A woman of extraordinary stature, strength, and courage; a woman who has the robust body and masculine mind of a man; a female warrior.
Vascularity: The quality or state of being vascular.
Viscus: One of the organs, as the brain, heart, or stomach, in the great cavities of the body of an animal; -- especially used in the plural, and applied to the organs contained in the abdomen.
Viscum: A genus of parasitic shrubs, including the mistletoe of Europe.
Vifda: In the Orkney and Shetland Islands, beef and mutton hung and dried, but not salted.
Vermetus: Any one of many species of marine gastropods belonging to Vermetus and allied genera, of the family Vermetidæ. Their shells are regularly spiral when young, but later in life the whorls become separate, and the shell is often irregularly bent and contorted like a worm tube.
Variorum: Containing notes by different persons; -- applied to a publication; as, a variorum edition of a book.
Varicose: Irregularly swollen or enlarged; affected with, or containing, varices, or varicosities; of or pertaining to varices, or varicosities; as, a varicose nerve fiber; a varicose vein; varicose ulcers.
Vitrifiable: Capable of being vitrified, or converted into glass by heat and fusion; as, flint and alkalies are vitrifiable.
Volvulus: The spasmodic contraction of the intestines which causes colic.
Voodooism: A degraded form of superstition and sorcery, said to include human sacrifices and cannibalism in some of its rites. It is prevalent among the negroes of Haiti, and to some extent in the United States, and is regarded as a relic of African barbarism.
Vol-au-vent: A light puff paste, with a raised border, filled, after baking, usually with a ragout of fowl, game, or fish.
Vinosity: The quality or state of being vinous.
Villanage: The state of a villain, or serf; base servitude; tenure on condition of doing the meanest services for the lord.
Vinum: Wine, -- chiefly used in Pharmacy in the name of solutions of some medicinal substance in wine; as: vina medicata, medicated wines; vinum opii, wine of opium.
Vintage: The produce of the vine for one season, in grapes or in wine; as, the vintage is abundant; the vintage of 1840.
Valkyria: One of the maidens of Odin, represented as awful and beautiful, who presided over battle and marked out those who were to be slain, and who also ministered at the feasts of heroes in Valhalla.  Now commonly written Valkyrie.
Vill: A small collection of houses; a village.
Victimize: To make a victim of, esp. by deception; to dupe; to cheat.
Vergency: The act of verging or approaching; tendency; approach.
Verbatim: Word for word; in the same words; verbally; as, to tell a story verbatim as another has related it.
Volumist: One who writes a volume; an author.
Virus: Contagious or poisonous matter, as of specific ulcers, the bite of snakes, etc.; -- applied to organic poisons.
Vasiform: Having the form of a vessel, or duct.
Vacuum: A space entirely devoid of matter (called also, by way of distinction, absolute vacuum); hence, in a more general sense, a space, as the interior of a closed vessel, which has been exhausted to a high or the highest degree by an air pump or other artificial means; as, water boils at a reduced temperature in a vacuum.
Visionariness: The quality or state of being visionary.
Vend\u00e9miaire: The first month of the French republican calendar, dating from September 22, 1792.
Vibices: More or less extensive patches of subcutaneous extravasation of blood.
Vitrificate: To convert into glass; to vitrify.
vivid: True to the life; exhibiting the appearance of life or freshness; animated; spirited; bright; strong; intense; as, vivid colors.
Voidance: The act of voiding, emptying, ejecting, or evacuating.
Verticle: An axis; a hinge; a turning point.
Vivarium: A place artificially arranged for keeping or raising living animals, as a park, a pond, an aquarium, a warren, etc.
Vasectomy: Resection or excision of the vas deferens.
Voluntariness: The quality or state of being voluntary; spontaneousness; specifically, the quality or state of being free in the exercise of one's will.
Vaticanism: The doctrine of papal supremacy; extreme views in support of the authority of the pope; ultramontanism; -- a term used only by persons who are not Roman Catholics.
Vanning: A process by which ores are washed on a shovel, or in a vanner.
Vanadinite: A mineral occurring in yellowish, brownish, and ruby-red hexagonal crystals.  It consists of lead vanadate with a small proportion of lead chloride.
Ventricle: A cavity, or one of the cavities, of an organ, as of the larynx or the brain; specifically, the posterior chamber, or one of the two posterior chambers, of the heart, which receives the blood from the auricle and forces it out from the heart.  See Heart.
Vaporization: The act or process of vaporizing, or the state of being converted into vapor; the artificial formation of vapor; specifically, the conversion of water into steam, as in a steam boiler.
Vitalize: To endow with life, or vitality; to give life to; to make alive; as, vitalized blood.
Venerean: Devoted to the offices of Venus, or love; venereal.
Venerability: The quality or state of being venerable; venerableness.
Vocalization: The act of vocalizing, or the state of being vocalized.
Vitals: Organs that are necessary for life; more especially, the heart, lungs, and brain.
Variable: That which is variable; that which varies, or is subject to change.
Vapid: Having lost its life and spirit; dead; spiritless; insipid; flat; dull; unanimated; as, vapid beer; a vapid speech; a vapid state of the blood.
Vectitation: The act of carrying, or state of being carried.
Variegated: Having marks or patches of different colors; as, variegated leaves, or flowers.
Vocalic: Of or pertaining to vowel sounds; consisting of the vowel sounds.
Veritable: Agreeable to truth or to fact; actual; real; true; genuine.
Vaulter: One who vaults; a leaper; a tumbler.
Vaulted: Arched; concave; as, a vaulted roof.
Validly: In a valid manner; so as to be valid.
Viennese: Of or pertaining to Vienna, or the people of Vienna.
Vagrant: One who strolls from place to place; one who has no settled habitation; an idle wanderer; a sturdy beggar; an incorrigible rogue; a vagabond.
Vigesimal: Twentieth; divided into, or consisting of, twenties or twenty parts.
Vespiary: A nest, or habitation, of insects of the wasp kind.
Vultern: The brush turkey (Talegallus Lathami) of Australia.  See Brush turkey.
Vigil: Abstinence from sleep, whether at a time when sleep is customary or not; the act of keeping awake, or the state of being awake; sleeplessness; wakefulness; watch.
Voltaplast: A form of voltaic, or galvanic, battery suitable for use electrotyping.
Vitriol: To dip in dilute sulphuric acid; to pickle.
Vanner: A machine for concentrating ore. See Frue vanner.
Violone: The largest instrument of the bass-viol kind, having strings tuned an octave below those of the violoncello; the contrabasso; -- called also double bass.
V hook: A gab at the end of an eccentric rod, with long jaws, shaped like the letter V.
Vodanium: A supposed element, afterward found to be a mixture of several metals, as copper, iron, lead, nickel, etc.
Virgulate: Shaped like a little twig or rod.
Vade mecum: A book or other thing that a person carries with him as a constant companion; a manual; a handbook.
Vox angelica: An organ stop of delicate stringlike quality, having for each finger key a pair of pipes, of which one is tuned slightly sharp to give a wavy effect to their joint tone.
Violine: A pale yellow amorphous substance of alkaloidal nature and emetic properties, said to have been extracted from the root and foliage of the violet (Viola).
Vacuolated: Full of vacuoles, or small air cavities; as, vacuolated cells.
Vespillo: One who carried out the dead bodies of the poor at night for burial.
Vallancy: A large wig that shades the face.
Village: A small assemblage of houses in the country, less than a town or city.
Vitriolation: The act, process, or result of vitriolating.
Velocimeter: An apparatus for measuring speed, as of machinery or vessels, but especially of projectiles.
Vermeil: Vermilion; also, the color of vermilion, a bright, beautiful red.
Velutinous: Having the surface covered with a fine and dense silky pubescence; velvety; as, a velutinous leaf.
Veterinary: Of or pertaining to the art of healing or treating the diseases of domestic animals, as oxen, horses, sheep, various pets, etc.; as, a veterinary writer or school.
Viperous: Having the qualities of a viper; malignant; venomous; as, a viperous tongue.
Vortex theory: The theory, advanced by Thomson (Lord Kelvin) on the basis of investigation by Helmholtz, that the atoms are vortically moving ring-shaped masses (or masses of other forms having a similar internal motion) of a homogeneous, incompressible, frictionless fluid. Various properties of such atoms (vortex atoms) can be mathematically deduced.  This theory is now (1998) obsolete, and has been superseded by quantum mechanics, which provides more accurate and detailed explanations of atomic behavior.
Vindicate: To lay claim to; to assert a right to; to claim.
Vaginate: Invested with, or as if with, a sheath; as, a vaginate stem, or one invested by the tubular base of a leaf.
Vaginati: A tribe of birds comprising the sheathbills.
Vibrancy: The state of being vibrant; resonance.
Vesuvine: A trade name for a brown dyestuff obtained from certain basic azo compounds of benzene; -- called also Bismarck brown, Manchester brown, etc.
Vagal: Of or pertaining to the vagus, or pneumogastric nerves; pneumogastric.
Vermes: An extensive artificial division of the animal kingdom, including the parasitic worms, or helminths, together with the nemerteans, annelids, and allied groups. By some writers the branchiopods, the bryzoans, and the tunicates are also included. The name was used in a still wider sense by Linnæus and his followers.
Veal: The flesh of a calf when killed and used for food.
Veerable: Changeable; shifting; as, winds veerable to southwest.
Vicissy duck: A West Indian duck, sometimes domesticated.
Vernacularization: The act or process of making vernacular, or the state of being made vernacular.
Vinedresser: One who cultivates, prunes, or cares for, grapevines; a laborer in a vineyard.
Vandal: Of or pertaining to the Vandals; resembling the Vandals in barbarism and destructiveness.
Vitriolizable: Capable of being converted into a vitriol.
Vacillation: The act of vacillating; a moving one way and the other; a wavering.
Visionary: One whose imagination is disturbed; one who sees visions or phantoms.
Volumed: Having the form of a volume, or roil; as, volumed mist.
Vizierate: The office, dignity, or authority of a vizier.
Volatilization: The act or process of volatilizing, or rendering volatile; the state of being volatilized.
Vote: To choose by suffrage; to elec&unr_;; as, to vote a candidate into office.
Vest: To come or descend; to be fixed; to take effect, as a title or right; -- followed by in; as, upon the death of the ancestor, the estate, or the right to the estate, vests in the heir at law.
Vomitive: Causing the ejection of matter from the stomach; emetic.
Ventro-inguinal: Pertaining both to the abdomen and groin, or to the abdomen and inguinal canal; as, ventro-inguinal hernia.
Vese: Onset; rush; violent draught or wind.
Venation: The act or art of hunting, or the state of being hunted.
Vingt et un: A game at cards, played by two or more persons. The fortune of each player depends upon obtaining from the dealer such cards that the sum of their pips, or spots, is twenty-one, or a number near to it; -- also called blackjack, or twenty-one.
Velout\u00e9: A white sauce or stock made by boiling down ham, veal, beef, fowl, bouillon, etc., then adding soup stock, seasoning, vegetables, and thickening, and again boiling and straining.
Vernation: The arrangement of the leaves within the leaf bud, as regards their folding, coiling, rolling, etc.; prefoliation.
Vis major: A superior force which under certain circumstances is held to exempt from contract obligations; inevitable accident; -- a civil-law term used as nearly equivalent to, but broader than, the common-law term act of God (which see).
Voltagraphy: In electrotypy, the act or art of copying, in metals deposited by electrolytic action, a form or pattern which is made the negative electrode.
Vaseline: A yellowish translucent substance, almost odorless and tasteless, obtained as a residue in the purification of crude petroleum, and consisting essentially of a mixture of several of the higher members of the paraffin series. It is used as an unguent, and for various purposes in the arts. See the Note under Petrolatum.
Volcanist: One versed in the history and phenomena of volcanoes.
Velocipedist: One who rides on a velocipede; a cyclist.
Vituperation: The act of vituperating; abuse; severe censure; blame.
Vedette: A sentinel, usually on horseback, stationed on the outpost of an army, to watch an enemy and give notice of danger; a vidette.
Viminal: Of or pertaining to twigs; consisting of twigs; producing twigs.
Vellum: A fine kind of parchment, usually made from calfskin, and rendered clear and white, -- used as for writing upon, and for binding books.
Vespertilionine: Of or pertaining to the Vespertiliones.
Viewless: Not perceivable by the eye; invisible; unseen.
Virtu: A love of the fine arts; a taste for curiosities.
Vamp: To provide, as a shoe, with new upper leather; hence, to to piece, as any old thing, with a new part; to repair; to patch; -- often followed by up.
Vanadous: Of or pertaining to vanadium; obtained from vanadium; -- said of an acid containing one equivalent of vanadium and two of oxygen; specifically, designating those compounds in which vanadium has a lower valence as contrasted with the vanadic compounds; as, vanadous acid
Volitient: Exercising the will; acting from choice; willing, or having power to will.
Variant: Something which differs in form from another thing, though really the same; as, a variant from a type in natural history; a variant of a story or a word.
Valved: Having a valve or valves; valvate.
Valetudinarian: A person of a weak or sickly constitution; one who is seeking to recover health.
Valance: To furnish with a valance; to decorate with hangings or drapery.
Voluminous: Of or pertaining to volume or volumes.
Vantage game: The first game after the set is deuce. See Set, n., 9.
Volador: A flying fish of California (Exocœtus Californicus): -- called also volator.
Vomerine: Of or pertaining to the vomer.
Vergett\u00e9: Divided by pallets, or pales; paly.
vitamin p: a water-soluble vitamin that maintains the resistance of cell and capillary walls to permeation.
Veadar: The thirteenth, or intercalary, month of the Jewish ecclesiastical calendar, which is added about every third year.
Volant: Passing through the air upon wings, or as if upon wings; flying; hence, passing from place to place; current.
Viduation: The state of being widowed or bereaved; loss; bereavement.
Vambrace: The piece designed to protect the arm from the elbow to the wrist.
Vitellin: An albuminous body, belonging to the class of globulins, obtained from yolk of egg, of which it is the chief proteid constituent, and from the seeds of many plants. From the latter it can be separated in crystalline form.
Voyageable: That may be sailed over, as water or air; navigable.
vitamin B: a group of water-soluble vitamins originally thought to be a single vitamin but now separated into several B vitamins.
vitamin A: any of several related fat-soluble vitamins (such as retinol) essential for normal vision; it also prevents night blindness or inflammation or dryness of the eyes.
vitamin E: a fat-soluble vitamin that is essential for normal reproduction.  It is found in vegetable oils, butter, and eggs.
vitamin D: any of several chemically related fat-soluble vitamins that prevent rickets.  It is found in fish-liver oils, egg yolks and milk.  Component vitamin D2 is also called calciferol, and vitamin D3 is called cholecalciferol.
vitamin K: either of two fat-soluble vitamins (vitamin K1 or vitamin K2) that help clot blood by participating in the fromation of prothrombin.
vitamin H: a B vitamin that aids in body growth.
Verjuice: The sour juice of crab apples, of green or unripe grapes, apples, etc.; also, an acid liquor made from such juice.
Volunteer: To enter into, or offer for, any service of one's own free will, without solicitation or compulsion; as, he volunteered in that undertaking.
Vernacularly: In a vernacular manner; in the vernacular.
Verumontanum: An elevation, or crest, in the wall of the urethra where the seminal ducts enter it.
Velveteen: A kind of cloth, usually cotton, made in imitation of velvet; cotton velvet.
Venue: A neighborhood or near place; the place or county in which anything is alleged to have happened; also, the place where an action is laid.
Vainly: In a vain manner; in vain.
Venus: The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or love deified.
Volksraad: A legislative assembly or parliament of any one of several countries colonized by the Dutch, esp. that of the South African Republic, or the Transvaal, and that of the Orange Free State.
Viary: Of or pertaining to roads; happening on roads.
Vein quartz: Quartz occurring as gangue in a vein.
Vitis: A genus of plants including all true grapevines.
Veneer: A thin leaf or layer of a more valuable or beautiful material for overlaying an inferior one, especially such a thin leaf of wood to be glued to a cheaper wood; hence, external show; gloss; false pretense.
Vers: A verse or verses.  See Verse, n.
Vert: Everything that grows, and bears a green leaf, within the forest; as, to preserve vert and venison is the duty of the verderer.
Villanella: An old rustic dance, accompanied with singing.
Very: In a high degree; to no small extent; exceedingly; excessively; extremely; as, a very great mountain; a very bright sun; a very cold day; the river flows very rapidly; he was very much hurt.
Vehmic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, certain secret tribunals which flourished in Germany from the end of the 12th century to the middle of the 16th, usurping many of the functions of the governments which were too weak to maintain law and order, and inspiring dread in all who came within their jurisdiction.
Verbenate: To strew with verbena, or vervain, as in ancient sacrifices and rites.
Verd: The privilege of cutting green wood within a forest for fuel.
Vilayet: One of the chief administrative divisions or provinces of the Ottoman Empire; -- formerly called eyalet.
Vanity box: A small box, usually jeweled or of precious metal and worn on a chain, containing a mirror, powder puff, and other small toilet articles for a woman.
Varisse: An imperfection on the inside of the hind leg in horses, different from a curb, but at the same height, and often growing to an unsightly size.
Verification: The act of verifying, or the state of being verified; confirmation; authentication.
Varanus: A genus of very large lizards native of Asia and Africa.  It includes the monitors. See Monitor, 3.
Ventiduct: A passage for wind or air; a passage or pipe for ventilating apartments.
Vaporizer: One who, or that which, vaporizes, or converts into vapor.
Vesical: Of or pertaining to the bladder.
Verminly: Resembling vermin; in the manner of vermin.
Volcanity: The quality or state of being volcanic, or volcanic origin; volcanicity.
Variety store: a retail store selling a wide variety of items, especially of low price, as in a five and ten.
Veratric: Pertaining to, or derived from, plants of the genus Veratrum.
Volatile: A winged animal; wild fowl; game.
Voluntaryism: The principle of supporting a religious system and its institutions by voluntary association and effort, rather than by the aid or patronage of the state.
Vomer: A bone, or one of a pair of bones, beneath the ethmoid region of the skull, forming a part a part of the partition between the nostrils in man and other mammals.
Venatic: Of or pertaining to hunting; used in hunting.
Vimineous: Of or pertaining to twigs; made of pliant twigs.
Virility: The quality or state of being virile; developed manhood; manliness; specif., the power of procreation; as, exhaustion.
Vesses: A kind of worsted; also, a worsted cloth.
Vermivorous: Devouring worms; feeding on worms; as, vermivorous birds.
Vilify: To make vile; to debase; to degrade; to disgrace.
Veteran: One who has been long exercised in any service or art, particularly in war; one who has had much experience, or has grown old or decrepit in service.
Vitrescence: The quality or state of being vitreous; glassiness, or the quality of being vitrescent; capability of conversion into glass; susceptibility of being formed into glass.
Vaporific: Producing vapor; tending to pass, or to cause to pass, into vapor; thus, volatile fluids are vaporific; heat is a vaporific agent.
Visor: A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.
Vellicative: Having the power of vellicating, plucking, or twitching; causing vellication.
Vindicative: Tending to vindicate; vindicating; as, a vindicative policy.
Varangian: One of the Northmen who founded a dynasty in Russia in the 9th century; also, one of the Northmen composing, at a later date, the imperial bodyguard at Constantinople.
Vulcanic: Of or pertaining to Vulcan; made by Vulcan; Vulcanian.
Vespers: One of the little hours of the Breviary.
Vixenish: Of or pertaining to a vixen; resembling a vixen.
Validness: The quality or state of being valid.
Vehicular: Of or pertaining to a vehicle; serving as a vehicle; as, a vehicular contrivance.
Vindicator: One who vindicates; one who justifies or maintains.
Vapor: To send off in vapor, or as if in vapor; as, to vapor away a heated fluid.
Valeramide: The acid amide derivative of valeric acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Varioloid: The smallpox as modified by previous inoculation or vaccination.
Vulpicide: One who kills a fox, except in hunting; also, the act of so killing a fox.
Vociferator: One who vociferates, or is clamorous.
Vulgate: Of or pertaining to the Vulgate, or the old Latin version of the Scriptures.
Vanessa: Any one of numerous species of handsomely colored butterflies belonging to Vanessa and allied genera. Many of these species have the edges of the wings irregularly scalloped.
Visitatorial: Of or pertaining to visitation, or a judicial visitor or superintendent; visitorial.
Vorticella: Any one of numerous species of ciliated Infusoria belonging to Vorticella and many other genera of the family Vorticellidæ.  They have a more or less bell-shaped body with a circle of vibrating cilia around the oral disk. Most of the species have slender, contractile stems, either simple or branched.
Versatility: The quality or state of being versatile; versatileness.
Vouchsafe: To condescend; to deign; to yield; to descend or stoop.
Vomito: The yellow fever in its worst form, when it is usually attended with black vomit.  See Black vomit.
Visualizer: One who visualizes or is proficient in visualization;
Vicine: An alkaloid extracted from the seeds of the vetch (Vicia sativa) as a white crystalline substance.
Vicarious: Of or pertaining to a vicar, substitute, or deputy; deputed; delegated; as, vicarious power or authority.
Vocation: A call; a summons; a citation; especially, a designation or appointment to a particular state, business, or profession.
Vowelish: Of the nature of a vowel.
Vesture: A garment or garments; a robe; clothing; dress; apparel; vestment; covering; envelope.
Ventriloquize: To practice ventriloquism; to speak like a ventriloquist.
Vacuum cleaner: A machine for cleaning carpets, tapestry, upholstered work, etc., by suction; -- sometimes called a vacuum.
Vastly: To a vast extent or degree; very greatly; immensely.
Vintner: One who deals in wine; a wine seller, or wine merchant.
Venulose: Full of venules, or small veins.
Vesicatory: Tending, or having power, to raise a blister.
vitamin K1: one of the two K vitamins, (C31H46O2).  It is fat-soluble and occurs naturally as the trans isomer. Chemically it is 2-methyl-3-phytyl-1,4,-naphthoquinone.
vitamin K3: menadione, (C11H8O2) being chemically 2-methyl-1,4,-naphthoquinone.  Having no side chain in the 3 position, it cannot exert all functions of a true K vitamin and the designation as vitamin K3 has been discouraged
vitamin K2: one of the two K vitamins, actually a mixture of homologous fat-soluble substituted naphthoquinones (called menaquinones), (C11H7O2[C5H8]nH), where n may be 1 to 13 but is mostly 7 to 9.  The term is also used for synthetic compounds resembling vitamin K2 and having the same physiological action.  The individual components of vitamin K2 are also referred to by the number of isoprenyl units in the side chain (the number n in the formula), as for menadione, having no units at that position of the naphthaquinone ring, and also called vitamin K2(0) (and also called vitamin K3).
Villainy: The quality or state of being a villain, or villainous; extreme depravity; atrocious wickedness; as, the villainy of the seducer.
Viewy: Having peculiar views; fanciful; visionary; unpractical; as, a viewy person.
Volcanic wind: A wind associated with a volcanic outburst and due to the eruption or to convection currents over hot lava.
Voraginous: Pertaining to a gulf; full of gulfs; hence, devouring.
Vinasse: The waste liquor remaining in the process of making beet sugar, -- used in the manufacture of potassium carbonate.
vitamin C: a vitamin that prevents scurvy.  Also called ascorbic acid.
Varletry: The rabble; the crowd; the mob.
Vaza parrot: Any one of several species of parrots of the genus Coracopsis, native of Madagascar; -- called also vasa parrot.
Verticil: A circle either of leaves or flowers about a stem at the same node; a whorl.
Vivandier: In Continental armies, esp. the French, a sutler.
Verdin: A small yellow-headed bird (Auriparus flaviceps) of Lower California, allied to the titmice; -- called also goldtit.
Vitriolize: To convert into a vitriol; to vitriolate.
Viverra: A genus of carnivores which comprises the civets.
Vestibule: To furnish with a vestibule or vestibules.
Vase-shaped: Formed like a vase, or like a common flowerpot.
Vallatory: Of or pertaining to a vallation; used for a vallation; as, vallatory reeds.
Vituperate: To find fault with; to scold; to overwhelm with wordy abuse; to censure severely or abusively; to rate.
Verecundity: The quality or state of being verecund; modesty.
vitamin M: same as vitamin Bc; folic acid.
Vermeologist: One who treats of vermes, or worms; a helminthologist.
Voir dire: An oath administered to a witness, usually before being sworn in chief, requiring him to speak the truth, or make true answers in reference to matters inquired of, to ascertain his competency to give evidence.
Viking: One belonging to the pirate crews from among the Northmen, who plundered the coasts of Europe in the eighth, ninth, and tenth centuries.
Vermiformia: A tribe of worms including Phoronis.  See Phoronis.
Valerian: Any plant of the genus Valeriana. The root of the officinal valerian (Valeriana officinalis) has a strong smell, and is much used in medicine as an antispasmodic.
Versifier: One who versifies, or makes verses; as, not every versifier is a poet.
Visitable: Liable or subject to be visited or inspected.
Vilipend: To value lightly; to depreciate; to slight; to despise.
Vierkleur: The four-colored flag of the South African Republic, or Transvaal, -- red, white, blue, and green.
Villiform: Having the form or appearance of villi; like close-set fibers, either hard or soft; as, the teeth of perch are villiform.
Violoncello: A stringed instrument of music; a bass viol of four strings, or a bass violin with long, large strings, giving sounds an octave lower than the viola, or tenor or alto violin.
Vinculum: A bond of union; a tie.
Violin: A small instrument with four strings, played with a bow; a fiddle.
Volta: A turning; a time; -- chiefly used in phrases signifying that the part is to be repeated one, two, or more times; as, una volta, once.  Seconda volta, second time, points to certain modifications in the close of a repeated strain.
Vitriform: Having the form or appearance of glass; resembling glass; glasslike.
Violate: To treat in a violent manner; to abuse.
Verify: To prove to be true or correct; to establish the truth of; to confirm; to substantiate.
Vacuity: The quality or state of being vacuous, or not filled; emptiness; vacancy; as, vacuity of mind; vacuity of countenance.
Veney: A bout; a thrust; a venew.
Volume: A roll; a scroll; a written document rolled up for keeping or for use, after the manner of the ancients.
Vant Hoffs law: The generalization that: when a system is in equilibrium, of the two opposed interactions the endothermic is promoted by raising the temperature, the exothermic by lowering it.
Venew: A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.
Victoria: A genus of aquatic plants named in honor of Queen Victoria.  The Victoria regia is a native of Guiana and Brazil.  Its large, spreading leaves are often over five feet in diameter, and have a rim from three to five inches high; its immense rose-white flowers sometimes attain a diameter of nearly two feet.
vitamin B12: a B vitamin that is used to treat pernicious anemia.
Viridine: A greenish, oily, nitrogenous hydrocarbon, C12H19N7, obtained from coal tar, and probably consisting of a mixture of several metameric compounds which are higher derivatives of the base pyridine.
Vitruvian: Of or pertaining to Vitruvius, an ancient Roman architect.
Vermicide: A medicine which destroys intestinal worms; a worm killer.
Volcano: A mountain or hill, usually more or less conical in form, from which lava, cinders, steam, sulphur gases, and the like, are ejected; -- often popularly called a burning mountain.
Veracious: Observant of truth; habitually speaking truth; truthful; as, veracious historian.
Vesicoprostatic: Of or pertaining to the bladder and the prostate gland.
Vaticinate: To prophesy; to foretell; to practice prediction; to utter prophecies.
Vanilloes: An inferior kind of vanilla, the pods of Vanilla Pompona.
Victim: A living being sacrificed to some deity, or in the performance of a religious rite; a creature immolated, or made an offering of.
Vorticose: Vortical; whirling; as, a vorticose motion.
Vinegar fly: Any of several fruit flies, esp. Drosophila ampelopophila, which breed in imperfectly sealed preserves and in pickles.
Vocable: A word; a term; a name; specifically, a word considered as composed of certain sounds or letters, without regard to its meaning.
Viability: The quality or state of being viable.
Vitrifacture: The manufacture of glass and glassware.
Veteranize: To reënlist for service as a soldier.
Versus: Against; as, John Doe versus Richard Roe; -- chiefly used in legal language, and abbreviated to v. or vs.
Venule: A small vein; a veinlet; specifically (Zoöl.), one of the small branches of the veins of the wings in insects.
Vendor: A vender; a seller; the correlative of vendee.
Vantage point: A point giving advantage; vantage ground.
Verve: Excitement of imagination such as animates a poet, artist, or musician, in composing or performing; rapture; enthusiasm; spirit; energy.
Vitriolization: The act of vitriolizing, or the state of being vitriolized; vitriolation.
V moth: A common gray European moth (Halia vauaria) having a V-shaped spot of dark brown on each of the fore wings.
Violaniline: A dyestuff of the induline group, made from aniline, and used as a substitute for indigo in dyeing wool and silk a violet-blue or a gray-blue color.
Vestryman: A member of a vestry; especially (Prot. Epis. Ch.), a member other than a warden.  See Vestry.
Voyage: To travel; to pass over; to traverse.
Vagus: Wandering; -- applied especially to the pneumogastric nerve.
Varied: Changed; altered; various; diversified; as, a varied experience; varied interests; varied scenery.
Virgo: A sign of the zodiac which the sun enters about the 21st of August, marked thus [&virgo_;] in almanacs.
Veinstone: The valueless nonmetalliferous mineral or rock material which surrounds the ores in a vein, as quartz, calcite, barite, fluor spar, etc.; gangue; matrix; -- called also veinstuff.
Varier: A wanderer; one who strays in search of variety.
Venous: Of or pertaining to a vein or veins; as, the venous circulation of the blood.
Verruculose: Minutely verrucose; as, a verruculose leaf or stalk.
Valve-shell: Any fresh-water gastropod of the genus Valvata.
Vesico-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to, the bladder; as in vesicoprostatic, vesicovaginal.
Vaulting: The act of constructing vaults; a vaulted construction.
Versor: The turning factor of a quaternion.
Volumenometry: The method or process of measuring volumes by means of the volumenometer.
Velella: Any species of oceanic Siphonophora belonging to the genus Velella.
Vocalist: A singer, or vocal musician, as opposed to an instrumentalist.
Vamplate: A round plate of iron on the shaft of a tilting spear, to protect the hand.
Vocalize: To form into voice; to make vocal or sonant; to give intonation or resonance to.
Verticalness: Quality or state of being vertical.
Vermifuge: A medicine or substance that expels worms from animal bodies; an anthelmintic.
Vetchy: Consisting of vetches or of pea straw.
Vagabond: To play the vagabond; to wander like a vagabond; to stroll.
Verticity: The quality or power of turning; revolution; rotation.
Vitrella: One of the transparent lenslike cells in the ocelli of certain arthropods.
Vestibulum: A cavity into which, in certain bryozoans, the esophagus and anus open.
Vertigo: Dizziness or swimming of the head; an affection of the head in which objects, though stationary, appear to move in various directions, and the person affected finds it difficult to maintain an erect posture; giddiness.
Veldt sore: An infective sore mostly on the hands and feet, often contracted in walking on the veldt and apparently due to a specific microörganism.
Vesicular: Of or pertaining to vesicles; esp., of or pertaining to the air vesicles, or air cells, of the lungs; as, vesicular breathing, or normal breathing, in which the air enters freely the air vesicles of the lungs.
Vulcanite: Hard rubber produced by vulcanizing with a large proportion of sulphur.
Vandyke: To fit or furnish with a Vandyke; to form with points or scallops like a Vandyke.
Viburnum: A genus of shrubs having opposite, petiolate leaves and cymose flowers, several species of which are cultivated as ornamental plants, as the laurestine and the guelder-rose.
Vicious: Characterized by vice or defects; defective; faulty; imperfect.
Vesbium: A rare metallic element of which little is known. It is said by Scacchi to have been extracted from a yellowish incrustation from the cracks of a Vesuvian lava erupted in 1631.
Vireo: Any one of numerous species of American singing birds belonging to Vireo and allied genera of the family Vireonidæ. In many of the species the back is greenish, or olive-colored.  Called also greenlet.
Vang: A rope to steady the peak of a gaff.
Valentinian: One of a school of Judaizing Gnostics in the second century; -- so called from Valentinus, the founder.
Vivification: The act of vivifying, or the state of being vivified; restoration of life; revival.
videocasette: a casette containing magnetic tape, which can be used in a videocasette recorder to record and play back electronic signals, such as from television programs.  The long magnetic tape in the videocasette is moved between two spindles, and a small portion of the tape at any one time is passed over a recording or playback head.
Villanelle: A poem written in tercets with but two rhymes, the first and third verse of the first stanza alternating as the third verse in each successive stanza and forming a couplet at the close.
Vitrifaction: The act, art, or process of vitrifying; also, the state of being vitrified.
Virulent: Extremely poisonous or venomous; very active in doing injury.
Venality: The quality or state of being venal, or purchasable; mercenariness; prostitution of talents, offices, or services, for money or reward; as, the venality of a corrupt court; the venality of an official.
Vendibility: The quality or state of being vendible, or salable.
Viridite: A greenish chloritic mineral common in certain igneous rocks, as diabase, as a result of alternation.
Vermilion: To color with vermilion, or as if with vermilion; to dye red; to cover with a delicate red.
Viridity: Greenness; verdure; the color of grass and foliage.
Vivify: To endue with life; to make to be living; to quicken; to animate.
